U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97650677



MARK: FLOTECH


Amended goods and services
Class 011
Bathtubs; Bath installations; Strainers for plumbing drains 

Deleted:
Faucets for pipes and pipelines being parts of sanitary installations; 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has U.S. Registration Nos. 5485640 and 6130110 as having a likelihood of confusion with the present application under 2d.

Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the following mark(s):

FLOWTEC, in standard characters, for "Handheld shower heads" in Class 11 (U.S. Registration No. 5485640)
FLOW, in stylized font, for "Faucets" in Class 11 (U.S. Registration No. 6130110:


The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
Registration FLOWTEC and FLOW both incorporate the word FLOW for shower heads and faucets, respectively, both of which allow water flow. The word FLOW is therefore descriptive of a characteristic of the product.

TEC sounds like TECH which is short for technology, which also describes a characteristic of the product, in that the product incorporates technology that allows water to flow at a controlled rate. 

Applicant’s mark FLOTECH has a unique design that differentiates the mark from the descriptive Registrations.

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The goods are different - the Registrations are for shower heads and faucets, and the application is for Bathtubs; Bath installations; Strainers for plumbing drains (as amended). Further, the channels of trade are different as bathtubs are generally too large to be sold through mail-order like Amazon.
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registrations do not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion.
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registrations.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the
mark in U.S. Registration No. 5271297. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see
TMEP §§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a
registered mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the
commercial source of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d).
Likelihood of confusion is determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in
In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A.
1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d
1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of record related to those factors need be considered;
however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant or of similar weight in every case.” In re
Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160, 1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re
Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533 (Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in
any likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322,
123 USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65,
64 USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544
F.2d 1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by
[Section] 2(d) goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the
goods [or services] and differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Applicant has applied to register the mark TOCK TICK PRESS in standard characters for
“Puzzles; Puzzles; Manipulative puzzles; Manipulative logic puzzles” in International Class 28.
Registrant’s mark is TICK TOCK POP in standard characters for “Board games; Manipulative
games; Parlour games; Party games; Tabletop games” in International Class 28.
Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317,
1321, 110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot
Ponsardin Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir.
2005)); TMEP §1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to
find the marks confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746
•
(TTAB 2018) (citing In re Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777
F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921 (Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, TOCK TICK PRESS, is confusingly similar to the registered mark,
TICK TOCK POP because they share the identical wording TOCK and TICK. Marks may be
confusingly similar in appearance where similar terms or phrases or similar parts of terms or
phrases appear in the compared marks and create a similar overall commercial impression. See
Crocker Nat’l Bank v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, 228 USPQ 689, 690-91 (TTAB
1986), aff’d sub nom. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce v. Wells Fargo Bank, Nat’l Ass’n,
811 F.2d 1490, 1495, 1 USPQ2d 1813, 1817 (Fed. Cir. 1987) (holding COMMCASH and
COMMUNICASH confusingly similar); In re Corning Glass Works, 229 USPQ 65, 66 (TTAB
1985) (holding CONFIRM and CONFIRMCELLS confusingly similar); In re Pellerin Milnor
Corp., 221 USPQ 558, 560 (TTAB 1983) (holding MILTRON and MILLTRONICS confusingly
similar); TMEP §1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii). Here, the marks share the identical
wording TOCK and TICK along with the words POP and PRESS that have a similar cadence
and meaning. Accordingly, the marks create the same commercial impression.
Even though the wording is transposed in the registered mark this does not obviate the
likelihoodc onfusion. of Confusion is likely between two marks consisting of reverse
combinations of the same elements if they convey the same meaning or create substantially
similar commercial impressions. TMEP §1207.01(b)(vii); see, e.g., Made in Nature, LLC v.
Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *2-5, *39-40 (TTAB 2022) (holding NATURE MADE
for various foods and beverages likely to be confused with MADE IN NATURE, and slight
variations of this mark, for various fresh and dried fruits, dried vegetables, fruit mixes, and fruit-
based snacks); In re Wine Soc’y of Am. Inc., 12 USPQ2d 1139, 1142 (TTAB 1989) (holding THE
WINE SOCIETY OF AMERICA and design for wine club membership services including the
supplying of printed materials likely to be confused with AMERICAN WINE SOCIETY 1967
and design for newsletters, bulletins, and journals); In re Nationwide Indus. Inc., 6 USPQ2d
1882, 1884 (TTAB 1988) (holding RUST BUSTER for a rust-penetrating spray lubricant likely
to be confused with BUST RUST for a penetrating oil).
The fact that the marks have additional wording POP and PRESS, this too does not avoid a
likelihood of confusion. First, the words both start with the letter "p" and have the strong "p"
sound. Second, the words have similar meanings. For example, "pop" means "to push, put, or
thrust suddenly or briefly" and "press" means "to act upon through steady pushing". See the
attached Merriam-Webster Dictionary definitions.
Because the marks look and sound similar and create the same commercial impression, the marks
are considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods
The goods are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related, or travel in
the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369-
71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of confusion.
See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475 (Fed.
Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the
goods and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning
LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v.
Wechsler, 83 USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature,
LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs
LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370, 1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Determining likelihood of confusion is based on the description of the goods and/or services
stated in the application and registration at issue, not on extrinsic evidence of actual use. See In
re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1307, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1052 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In
re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1325, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1749 (Fed. Cir. 2017)).
In this case, the registration(s) use(s) broad wording to describe "Board games; Manipulative
games; Parlour games; Party games; Tabletop games", which presumably encompasses all
goods of the type described, including applicant’s more narrow " Puzzles; Puzzles; Manipulative
puzzles; Manipulative logic puzzles" . See, e.g., Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022
USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022); In re Solid State Design Inc., 125 USPQ2d 1409, 1412-15
(TTAB 2018); Sw. Mgmt., Inc. v. Ocinomled, Ltd., 115 USPQ2d 1007, 1025 (TTAB 2015).
Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods are legally identical. See, e.g., In re i.am.symbolic, llc,
127 USPQ2d 1627, 1629 (TTAB 2018) (citing Tuxedo Monopoly, Inc. v. Gen. Mills Fun Grp.,
Inc., 648 F.2d 1335, 1336, 209 USPQ 986, 988 (C.C.P.A. 1981); Inter IKEA Sys. B.V. v. Akea,
LLC, 110 USPQ2d 1734, 1745 (TTAB 2014); Baseball Am. Inc. v. Powerplay Sports Ltd., 71
USPQ2d 1844, 1847 n.9 (TTAB 2004)).
Additionally, the goods of the parties have no restrictions as to nature, type, channels of trade, or
classes of purchasers and are “presumed to travel in the same channels of trade to the same class
of purchasers.” In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir.
2012) (quoting Hewlett-Packard Co. v. Packard Press, Inc., 281 F.3d 1261, 1268, 62 USPQ2d
1001, 1005 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at
*49. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are related.
Accordingly, the goods are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of confusion
analysis.
Conclusion
Because the marks are similar and the goods are related, there is a likelihood of confusion as to
the source of applicant’s goods, and registration is refused pursuant to Section 2(d) of the
Trademark Act.
completion:
U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97547520

MARK: TOCK TICK PRESS

Amended Goods and services
Class 028
Puzzles; Puzzles; Manipulative puzzles; Manipulative logic puzzles

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 5271297 for TICK TOCK POP in standard
characters for “Board games; Manipulative games; Parlour games; Party games; Tabletop
games” in International Class 28. as having a likelihood of confusion with the application
under 2d.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to
determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial
impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a
connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect
"when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in
the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all
of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476
F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):

1. The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance,
sound, connotation and commercial impression.

The registrant’s TICK TOCK POP provides a connotation of a clock counting down and a
OPO when the countdown has completed, wherein something pops. This is emphasized
with the logo wherein the POP is shown in a red comic-book explosion type font.

The application is for TOCK TICK PRESS, which is the name of a press, or printer. TOCK
TICK also evokes a clock (with the sounds reversed) but not a timer running out with a pop at the end. Rather, Press refers to the sedentary business activity of reviewing and printing books for people to read. 

The phrase 'tock tick', as distinct from, or when compared to 'tick tock' is referred to as an "Ablaut Reduplication" - in short there are linguistic rules as to the order of vowels and consonants in words that are repeated. The idea behind 'disobeying' those rules (i.e. choosing 'tock tick' as a name) is that it sounds or appears intuitively "wrong" in some sense, and marks it out as deliberately different from similar words which obey the Ablaut Reduplication formula. Accordingly, it is suggested that a trademark with the term 'tock tick' would not be confused with one including the 'correct' "tick tock", but rather acts as an almost automatic differentiating characteristic which would serve to highlight that whatever this 'tock tick press' is, it most certainly isn't a 'tick tock pop". The connotation is different between the marks due to the sound, appearance and goods/services but also the unique, memorable reversed form.

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that
differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man
Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE
MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that
applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the
marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v.
Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In
the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was
found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
2. The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described
in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in
Use.

Registration is for “Board games; Manipulative games; Parlour games; Party games;
Tabletop games” while Application is for “Puzzles; Puzzles; Manipulative puzzles;
Manipulative logic puzzles”. Puzzles are different from games as there is a problem to
solve rather than a game to play with (usually) another person.

Registration appears to be a game that ticks until the time runs out, when it “pops”. This
is quite different in game play from puzzles.

3. The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.

4. The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion.

It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that
there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
THIS REFUSAL APPLIES TO THE GOODS IN CLASS 009 ONLY.
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 6327308. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Similarity of the Marks
Applicant has applied to register the mark KEEP ON with a design owned by Anca Trading Group
LLC
Registrant’s mark is KEEPUON in standard characters owned by Shenzhen Danhong Home Textile Co.
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in meaning, appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, KEEP ON, is confusingly similar to the registered mark, KEEPUON in sound,
appearance, meaning, and overall commercial impression. The words are almost identical, taking the
"U" out of the registered mark and adding a power symbol in place of the "O" in applicant's mark. The
addition of the power symbol does not change the mark significantly enough to obviate confusion from
the registered mark. The marks both imply "keeping" something "on," in this case, referring to power,
as they both are used in commerce in relation to items used for and with providing power and charging
to devices.
When evaluating a composite mark consisting of words and a design, the word portion is normally
accorded greater weight because it is likely to make a greater impression upon purchasers, be
remembered by them, and be used by them to refer to or request the goods and/or services. In re
Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting CBS Inc. v.
Morrow, 708 F.2d 1579, 1581-82, 218 USPQ 198, 200 (Fed. Cir. 1983)); Made in Nature, LLC v.
Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *41 (TTAB 2022) (quoting Sabhnani v. Mirage Brands, LLC,
2021 USPQ2d 1241, at *31 (TTAB 2021)); TMEP §1207.01(c)(ii). Thus, although marks must be
compared in their entireties, the word portion is often considered the dominant feature and is accorded
greater weight in determining whether marks are confusingly similar, even where the word portion has
been disclaimed. In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d at 1366-67, 101 USPQ2d at 1911 (citing Giant Food, Inc.
v. Nation’s Foodservice, Inc., 710 F.2d 1565, 1570-71, 218 USPQ2d 390, 395 (Fed. Cir. 1983)).
The word portions of the marks, KEEP ON and KEEPUON are nearly identical in appearance, sound,
connotation, and commercial impression; therefore, the addition of a design element does not obviate
the similarity of the marks in this case. See In re Shell Oil Co., 992 F.2d 1204, 1206, 26 USPQ2d 1687,
1688 (Fed. Cir. 1993); TMEP §1207.01(c)(ii).
Because the marks look and sound similar, have the same meaning, and create the same commercial
impression, the marks are considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods and/or Services
Applicant has applied for “Cases adapted for holding smartwatches; Cell phone cases; Cell phone
holders for vehicles; Chargers for batteries; Chargers for electric batteries; Chargers for smartphones;
Holders adapted for mobile telephones and smartphones; Mouse pads; Screen protectors specially
adapted for mobile phones; USB cables for cellphones; USB charging ports; Battery chargers; Carrying
cases for cell phones; Dashboard mats specially adapted for holding mobile telephones and
smartphones; Electric charging cables; Electronic cables; Head-clip cell phone holders; Micro USB
cables; Mobile phone screen protectors; Protective cases for cell phones; Protective cases for laptop
computers; Protective cases for tablet computers; Protective covers and cases for cell phones;
Protective covers and cases for cell phones, laptops and portable media players; USB cables; Wireless
battery chargers" in International Class 009.
Registrant’s mark is for “Coaxial cables; Computer keypads; Earphones and headphones; Eyeglass
cases; Eyeglass frames; Masts for wireless aerials; Motorcycle helmets; Multi-outlet socket blocks;
Multimedia projectors; Protective ear covering shields; Radio and television aerials; Satellite aerials;
Skateboard helmets; Television antennas; Waterproof cases for smart phones” in International Class
009.
When analyzing an applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services for similarity and relatedness, that
determination is based on the description of the goods and/or services in the application and registration
at issue, not on extrinsic evidence of actual use. See Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital
LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1323, 110 USPQ2d 1157, 1162 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Octocom Sys. Inc. v.
Hous. Computers Servs. Inc., 918 F.2d 937, 942, 16 USPQ2d 1783, 1787 (Fed. Cir. 1990)).
Determining likelihood of confusion is based on the description of the goods and/or services stated in
the application and registration at issue, not on extrinsic evidence of actual use. See In re Detroit
Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1307, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1052 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1325, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1749 (Fed. Cir. 2017)).
In this case, the application uses broad wording to describe "cell phone cases; carrying cases for cell
phones; and protective cases for cell phones", which presumably encompasses all goods and/or services
of the type described, including registrant’s more narrow "waterproof cases for smart phones". See,
e.g., Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022); In re Solid
State Design Inc., 125 USPQ2d 1409, 1412-15 (TTAB 2018); Sw. Mgmt., Inc. v. Ocinomled, Ltd., 115
USPQ2d 1007, 1025 (TTAB 2015). Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods are legally identical. See,
e.g., In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 127 USPQ2d 1627, 1629 (TTAB 2018) (citing Tuxedo Monopoly, Inc. v.
Gen. Mills Fun Grp., Inc., 648 F.2d 1335, 1336, 209 USPQ 986, 988 (C.C.P.A. 1981); Inter IKEA Sys.
B.V. v. Akea, LLC, 110 USPQ2d 1734, 1745 (TTAB 2014); Baseball Am. Inc. v. Powerplay Sports Ltd.,
71 USPQ2d 1844, 1847 n.9 (TTAB 2004)).
Additionally, the goods and/or services of the parties have no restrictions as to nature, type, channels of
trade, or classes of purchasers and are “presumed to travel in the same channels of trade to the same
class of purchasers.” In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir.
2012) (quoting Hewlett-Packard Co. v. Packard Press, Inc., 281 F.3d 1261, 1268, 62 USPQ2d 1001,
1005 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *49. Thus,
applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are related.
The goods are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related, or travel in the
same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369-71, 101
USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1165,
64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods in International Class 009 are closely related to registrant’s goods because both
parties sell protective cases for phones along with other electronic devices and tech accessories
commonly sold by the same manufacturers and retailers. It is common for the same entity to produce
electronic goods and goods used with those electronics under the same mark. Thus, the goods have the
same class of purchasers and are likely to be encountered under circumstances that would cause one to
mistakenly believe the goods emanate from the same source.
The attached internet evidence, consisting of the websites for Samsung, Sony, and Apple, establishes
that the same entity commonly manufactures, produces, or provides the relevant goods and/or services
and markets the goods and/or services under the same mark. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods
and/or services are considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey
Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d
1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Different goods in the electrical, electronic, and/or electromechanical fields have been found to be
related where the evidence shows that the goods would be marketed through the same channels of trade
and/or sold to the same classes of purchasers. See, e.g., Alliance Mfg. Co. v. ABH Diversified Prods.,
Inc., 226 USPQ 348 (TTAB 1985) (finding cycling-type furnace controllers and various home
products, including garage door openers and remote controls for operating lights and appliances, to be
related, where both parties’ goods were electrically powered/electronically operated, had similar energy
conserving characteristics, and were sold for residential use); In re Globe-Union Inc., 189 USPQ 158,
159 (TTAB 1975) (finding resistor-capacitor components and ceramic condensers to be related, where
such goods “would be sold in the same trade channels to the same classes of purchasers such as original
equipment manufacture[r]s for incorporation in the same piece of electronic equipment or apparatus”);
In re Dynaco, Inc., 189 USPQ 104, 105 (TTAB 1975) (finding two-channel stereophonic amplifiers,
loudspeakers, and non-electronic devices for connecting amplifiers and speakers, on the one hand, and
switching transistors, on the other, to be related because the goods would be “invariably sold to the
same class of purchasers in such circumstances and conditions that if persons were to encounter them
under the same or similar marks, they might well be induced to believe that they originate from a
common source”); Nat'l Steel Constr. Co. v. Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co., 158 USPQ 464 (TTAB 1968)
(finding electric washing machines and electric water heaters to be related, where such goods were sold
through the same channels of trade to the same class of purchaser, where the purchase of one of the
party’s goods could lead to the purchase of the other party’s goods, and where the evidence of record
indicated that a single manufacturer might produce both electric washing machines and electric water
heaters).
Thus, upon encountering KEEP ON and KEEPUON used on the identified goods, consumers are likely
to be confused and mistakenly believe tht the respective goods emanate from a common source.
Accordingly, the goods and/or services are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of
confusion analysis.
Conclusion
Because the marks are similar and the goods are related, there is a likelihood of confusion as to the
source of applicant’s goods and/or services, and registration is refused pursuant to Section 2(d) of the
Trademark Act.
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration.

Amended goods and services

Class 009

Cases adapted for holding smartwatches; Cell phone cases; Cell phone holders for vehicles;  Holders adapted for mobile telephones and smartphones;  Screen protectors specially adapted for mobile phones; USB cables for cellphones; USB charging ports; Protective covers and cases for cell phones, laptops and portable media players; USB cables; Carrying cases for cell phones; Mobile phone screen protectors; Protective cases for cell phones; Protective cases for laptop computers; Protective cases for tablet computers; Protective covers and cases for cell phones; 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 6327308 (KEEPUON in class 009 for Coaxial cables; Computer keypads; Earphones and headphones; Eyeglass cases; Eyeglass frames; Masts for wireless aerials; Motorcycle helmets; Multi-outlet socket blocks; Multimedia projectors; Protective ear covering shields; Radio and television aerials; Satellite aerials; Skateboard helmets; Television antennas; Waterproof cases for smart phones ). 

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
The Registration is KEEPUON, formed of three words, KEEP, YOU and ON, so the products are intended to keep the consumer on (“you” referring to the consumer presumably), as in “keep you on the horse”) while application is KeepOn, with a Power-on sign as the O of On. This results in a different connotation as KEEP ON refers to the product instead of the consumer, especially in view of the power sign directing the consumer’s attention to power.


Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The application is for Class 003 for “Cleaner for use on screens, cell phones, tablets, computers” and Class 009 for “Chargers for batteries; Chargers for electric batteries; Chargers for smartphones; Mouse pads; Battery chargers; Dashboard mats specially adapted for holding mobile telephones and smartphones; Electric charging cables; Electronic cables; Head-clip cell phone holders; Micro USB cables; Wireless battery chargers ”(currently amended.)
The goods in class 009 have been amended to avoid similarity with goods in the other mark, which are “Coaxial cables; Computer keypads; Earphones and headphones; Eyeglass cases; Eyeglass frames; Masts for wireless aerials; Motorcycle helmets; Multi-outlet socket blocks; Multimedia projectors; Protective ear covering shields; Radio and television aerials; Satellite aerials; Skateboard helmets; Television antennas; Waterproof cases for smart phones.” Applicant has removed cases and holders for cell phones and cables: “Cases adapted for holding smartwatches; Cell phone cases; Cell phone holders for vehicles;  Holders adapted for mobile telephones and smartphones;  Screen protectors specially adapted for mobile phones; USB cables for cellphones; USB charging ports; Protective covers and cases for cell phones, laptops and portable media players; USB cables; Carrying cases for cell phones; Mobile phone screen protectors; Protective cases for cell phones; Protective cases for laptop computers; Protective cases for tablet computers; Protective covers and cases for cell phones; “ (currently deleted.)
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion.
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 5239426. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Applicant has applied to register the mark HUEMAN STUDIO in standard characters for “Brand
concept and brand development services for corporate and individual clients; Branding services,
namely, consulting, development, management and marketing of brands for businesses and/or
individuals” in International Class 35 and "Graphic design; Web site design" in International Class 42.
Registrant’s mark is HUEMAN in standard characters for, in pertinent part, “Promoting the goods and
services of others; Advertising and marketing services, namely, promoting the goods and services of
others” in International Class 35.
Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, HUEMAN STUDIO, is confusingly similar to the registered mark, HUEMAN
because the dominant portion of the applicant's mark is the registrant's mark.
Although marks are compared in their entireties, one feature of a mark may be more significant or
dominant in creating a commercial impression. See In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128
USPQ2d 1047, 1050 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re Dixie Rests., 105 F.3d 1405, 1407, 41 USPQ2d
1531, 1533-34 (Fed. Cir. 1997)); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii). Greater weight is often given to this
dominant feature when determining whether marks are confusingly similar. See In re Detroit Athletic
Co., 903 F.3d at 1305, 128 USPQ2d at 1050 (citing In re Dixie Rests., 105 F.3d at 1407, 41 USPQ2d at
1533-34).
Consumers are generally more inclined to focus on the first word, prefix, or syllable in any trademark
or service mark. See Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Maison Fondee En 1772, 396
F.3d 1369, 1372, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1692 (Fed. Cir. 2005) (finding similarity between VEUVE
ROYALE and two VEUVE CLICQUOT marks in part because “VEUVE . . . remains a ‘prominent
feature’ as the first word in the mark and the first word to appear on the label”); Century 21 Real Estate
Corp. v. Century Life of Am., 970 F.2d 874, 876, 23 USPQ2d 1698, 1700 (Fed Cir. 1992) (finding
similarity between CENTURY 21 and CENTURY LIFE OF AMERICA in part because “consumers
must first notice th[e] identical lead word”); see also In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1303,
128 USPQ2d 1047, 1049 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (finding “the identity of the marks’ two initial words is
particularly significant because consumers typically notice those words first”). In the present case, the
dominant portion of the applicant's mark is HUEMAN, the registrant's mark.
Incorporating the entirety of one mark within another does not obviate the similarity between the
compared marks, as in the present case, nor does it overcome a likelihood of confusion under Section
2(d). See Wella Corp. v. Cal. Concept Corp., 558 F.2d 1019, 1022, 194 USPQ 419, 422 (C.C.P.A.
1977) (holding CALIFORNIA CONCEPT and surfer design and CONCEPT confusingly similar);
Coca-Cola Bottling Co. v. Jos. E. Seagram & Sons, Inc., 526 F.2d 556, 557, 188 USPQ 105, 106
(C.C.P.A. 1975) (holding BENGAL LANCER and design and BENGAL confusingly similar); Double
Coin Holdings, Ltd. v. Tru Dev., 2019 USPQ2d 377409, at *6-7 (TTAB 2019) (holding ROAD
WARRIOR and WARRIOR (stylized) confusingly similar); In re Mr. Recipe, LLC, 118 USPQ2d 1084,
1090 (TTAB 2016) (holding JAWS DEVOUR YOUR HUNGER and JAWS confusingly similar);
TMEP §1207.01(b)(iii). In the present case, the marks are identical in part.
Because the marks look and sound similar and create the same commercial impression, the marks are
considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods and/or Services
The goods and/or services are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related,
or travel in the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356,
1369-71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods and/or services, “Brand concept and brand development services for corporate
and individual clients; Branding services, namely, consulting, development, management and
marketing of brands for businesses and/or individuals" and "Graphic design; Web site design,” are
closely related to registrant’s goods and/or services, “Promoting the goods and services of others;
Advertising and marketing services, namely, promoting the goods and services of others.”
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of Bolt Advertising, Adeasel, and Clay, establishes that the
same entity commonly manufactures, produces, or provides the relevant goods and/or services and
markets the goods and/or services under the same mark. Specifically, the evidence shows that brand
development services, website and graphic design services, and advertising and marketing services are
likely to emanate from the same source. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are
considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92
USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69,
1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Accordingly, the goods and/or services are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of
confusion analysis.

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97268969


MARK: HUEMAN STUDIO 
 


Amended goods and services
Class 035
Brand concept and brand development services for corporate and individual clients in the field of medical, technology, insurance, and nonprofit industries; Branding services, namely, consulting, development and brands for businesses and/or individuals in the field of medical, technology, insurance, and nonprofit industries

Deleted:
management and marketing of brands to business

Class 042
Web site design in the field of medical, technology, insurance, and nonprofit industries

Deleted:
Graphic design

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited registered mark U.S. Registration No. 5239426
 (HUEMAN in class 035 for Promoting the goods and services of others; Advertising and marketing services, namely, promoting the goods and services of others). 

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
The Registration is HUEMAN, distinguished from the Application HUEMAN STUDIO by the word STUDIO. HUEMAN in the Registration refers to a person whose artist name is HUEMAN (see enclosed) and whose surname is Hueman. 
The artist’s full name is Allison Hueman (see enclosed). HUEMAN is primarily a surname, since it is the artist’s surname and also the name of the applicant/registrant in that case, HUEMAN LLC. Surnames are not registrable without evidence of long and exclusive use, and that the evidence of distinctiveness delays appropriation of exclusive rights in the name:
The Trademark Act, in §2(e)(4), reflects the common law that exclusive rights in a surname per se cannot be established without evidence of long and exclusive use that changes its significance to the public from that of a surname to that of a mark for particular goods or services. The common law also recognizes that surnames are shared by more than one individual, each of whom may have an interest in using his surname in business; and, by the requirement for evidence of distinctiveness, the law, in effect, delays appropriation of exclusive rights in the name. In re Etablissements Darty et Fils, 759 F.2d 15, 17, 225 USPQ 652, 653 (Fed. Cir. 1985).
Despite this prohibition, no claim for acquired distinctiveness was filed in the Registration. 
HUEMAN also refers to  the artists as a person, but no consent has been provided in the record.
The goods and services are closely connected to that artist and her art in the mind of consumers. Consumers would not think that the artist HUEMAN is now providing branding advice (the Applicant’s services), for example. Consumers will expect the artist to provide artwork and exhibitions.
Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Registrant’s services are art in class 016 and art exhibition services in class 041. Registrant also has services in class 035 for “Promoting the goods and services of others; Advertising and marketing services, namely, promoting the goods and services of others” however, the Registrant’s specimen does not show use of these services. 
Applicant also has amended services in class 042, namely “ Web site design in the field of medical, technology, insurance, and nonprofit industries.” To further distinguish these from the services of the Registrant, the applicant has removed “management and marketing of brands to business” in class 035 and “Graphic design in the field of medical, technology, insurance, and nonprofit industries; “ in class 042. In class 035, the applicant participates in brand strategy, i.e selecting the brand name for companies, rather than marketing. These services are distinct from the Registrant’s marketing activities. 
These services are different from the Applicant’s in class 035, namely “Brand concept and brand development services for corporate and individual clients; Branding services, namely, consulting and development of brands for businesses and/or individuals,” which focuses on branding and brand concept rather than promotion, advertising, marketing of the Registrant. From Registrant’s specimen of use for class 041 there is some mention of some other partner brands on her Instagram - promotion as in mention in the brand, rather than marketing as it is normally understood. These are distinguished in channels of trade, wherein companies often provide one or the other, namely branding or promotion, rather than both. It is submitted that the services in class 035 travel through somewhat different channels of trade, and are different enough that consumers would understand the different connotations in view of the differences in the marks themselves.
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion.
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.
