Registration is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in RNs 2619835, 2619883,
2619884, 3315244, 3532840, and 5955766. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C.
§1052(d); see TMEP §§1207.01. See the previously attached registrations.
Applicant seeks to register NEW YORK PREMIUM OUTLET in standard characters for “On-line
retail store services featuring a wide variety of consumer goods of others; On-line retail store services
featuring bags, wallets, clothing, jewelry, shoes, t-shirts, jackets, hoodies, sportswear; the foregoing
excluding gift cards” in Class 35.
The cited marks are:
RN 2619835, DESERT HILLS PREMIUM OUTLETS in standard characters for "Management and
leasing of retail shopping mall space and retail shopping mall services" in Class 36.
RN 2619883, PREMIUM OUTLETS in standard characters for services including "Management and
leasing of retail shopping mall space and retail shopping mall services" in Class 36.
RN 2619884, PREMIUM OUTLET SHOPPING in standard characters for "Leasing of retail
shopping mall space and retail mall shopping services" in Class 36.
RN 3315244, PREMIUM OUTLETS in standard characters for services including "Business
management services in connection with retail shopping malls" in Class 35.
RN 3532840, WOODBURY COMMON PREMIUM OUTLETS in standard characters
for "Management and leasing of retail shopping mall space and retail shopping mall services" in Class
36.
RN 5955766, SHOP PREMIUM OUTLETS in standard characters for services including
"Administering a customer-loyalty program offering incentive rewards to consumers in order to
promote the sale of products/services by said featured third-party retailers" in Class 35.
The same entity owns RNs 2619835, 2619883, 2619884, 3315244, and 3532840. A different entity
owns RN 5955766.
Section 2(d) bars registration of a mark that is so similar to a registered mark that it is likely consumers
would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source of the services of the parties. See
15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the
factors from In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567
(C.C.P.A. 1973) (the “du Pont factors”). In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d
1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of record related to those factors must be considered, but
“not all of the DuPont factors are relevant or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co.,
912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160, 1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105
F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533 (Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarity of the marks; and (2) the relatedness of the
services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123 USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l,
Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir.
2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d 1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29
(C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d) goes to the cumulative effect of
differences in the essential characteristics of the [services] and differences in the marks.”); TMEP
§1207.01.
Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Marks may be confusingly similar in appearance when they contain similar terms that create a similar
overall commercial impression. See Crocker Nat’l Bank v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, 228
USPQ 689, 690-91 (TTAB 1986), aff’d sub nom. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce v. Wells
Fargo Bank, Nat’l Ass’n, 811 F.2d 1490, 1495, 1 USPQ2d 1813, 1817 (Fed. Cir. 1987) (finding
COMMCASH and COMMUNICASH confusingly similar); In re Corning Glass Works, 229 USPQ 65,
66 (TTAB 1985) (finding CONFIRM and CONFIRMCELLS confusingly similar); In re Pellerin
Milnor Corp., 221 USPQ 558, 560 (TTAB 1983) (finding MILTRON and MILLTRONICS confusingly
similar); TMEP §1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii).
Here, applicant’s mark is NEW YORK PREMIUM OUTLET in standard characters and the cited
marks are all forms of PREMIUM OUTLET(S) with additional geographic terms or a form of the word
SHOP. These marks have highly similar appearances, sounds, and commercial impressions because
each uses the identical phrase PREMIUM OUTLET(S) as its dominant term.
Same Overall Structure. Substituting names of different geographic locations and adding the generic
term SHOP or SHOPPING does not reduce the potential for confusion. Despite these minor variations,
applicant’s mark and the registered marks are all still structured around the same phrase PREMIUM
OUTLET(S), which conveys the same overall commercial impression of a high-quality shopping
center. See Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321, 110 USPQ2d
1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014). That common commercial impression may lead consumers to perceive
applicant's NEW YORK PREMIUM OUTLET as either: (1) the exact same brand as the other
PREMIUM OUTLET(S); or, if they notice the subtle variations between the marks, (2) some type of
related sub-brand or spin-off establishment. Section 2(d) bars registration of confusingly similar marks
to prevent this type of misunderstanding.
Weakness or Dilution. Applicant argues that "there are a lot of similar trademarks registered in many
trademark offices" and cites search results from the European IP Office and Philippines Trademark
Office. First Response, at 5-6, 8-9. But the weakness or dilution of a mark is determined in the context
of the number and nature of similar marks in use in United States interstate commerce—the only type
of commerce this Office has the authority to regulate. See TMEP §901.03 (detailing the scope of
Congress's authority to regulate commerce). Any foreign registrations are beyond the purview of this
Office and do not affect the likelihood of confusion determination. See id.
Registrations Are Presumptively Valid. Applicant also argues that PREMIUM or PREMIUM
OUTLET are "generic" terms, and that LOS ANGELES and NEW YORK are descriptive. First
Response, at 6-9; Second Response, at 2-4. But Trademark Act Section 7(b) provides that certificates of
registration on the Principal Register—which registrant has here—are prima facie evidence of the
validity of a registered mark. 15 U.S.C. §1057(b). The validity of a cited registration “cannot be
challenged in an ex parte proceeding.” In re Fat Boys Water Sports LLC, 118 USPQ2d 1511, 1517
(TTAB 2016). Accordingly, applicant’s arguments about the distinctiveness of the cited marks (or the
prior-pending applications which may become cited marks) will not be considered because to do so
would fail to give it the presumption of validity to which it are entitled. In re Fat Boys Water Sports
LLC, 118 USPQ2d at 1517 (citing In re Fiesta Palms LLC, 85 USPQ2d 1360, 1363 (TTAB 2007)).
Given the highly similar appearances, sounds, and commercial impressions of NEW YORK
PREMIUM OUTLET and the various registered forms of PREMIUM OUTLET(S) arising from the
shared dominant phrase PREMIUM OUTLET, applicant’s mark and the cited marks are confusingly
similar.
Relatedness of the Services
The compared services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of confusion. See
On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475 (Fed. Cir.
2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000); TMEP
§1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner” or have “the circumstances surrounding
their marketing [be] such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the services] emanate
from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101
USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83 USPQ2d 1715, 1724
(TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i).
The previously attached evidence from Destiny USA, Tanger, and Westfield establishes that the same
entity commonly offers, under the same trademark, both: (1) retail store services featuring clothing,
jewelry, bags, and other goods like applicant’s; and (2) shopping mall management, leasing, and loyalty
programs like registrants’. Given this overlap, these services are closely related for likelihood of
confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB
2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Lack of Identical Services. Applicant attempts to draw real-world distinctions between its business
and those of the prior-pending applicants', framing the latter as "large physical locations" and the
former as "only ... online retail services" Response, at 4. But the likelihood of confusion determination
does not turn on whether the applicant and registrant (or prior-pending applicant) provide identical
services. Since physical retail establishments likely also have a presence online, the potential for
confusion remains high. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56
USPQ2d 1471, 1475 (Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894,
1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i).
Consumer Sophistication & Standard of Care. Applicant also argues that some of the consumers
involved here are "sophisticated." Response, at 4. This does not reduce the potential for confusion for
several reasons. First, there is no evidence in the record establishing this higher standard of care.
Second, even if there were, the fact that purchasers are sophisticated or knowledgeable in a particular
field does not necessarily mean that they are sophisticated or knowledgeable in the field of trademarks
or immune from source confusion. TMEP §1207.01(d)(vii); see, e.g., Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP
v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d. 1317, 1325, 110 USPQ2d 1157, 1163-64 (Fed. Cir. 2014); Top Tobacco
LP v. N. Atl. Operating Co., 101 USPQ2d 1163, 1170 (TTAB 2011). Finally, where the purchasers
consist of both professionals and the public, as is presumably the case here absent any evidence to the
contrary, the standard of care for purchasing the services is that of the least sophisticated potential
purchaser. In re FCA US LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1214, 1222 (TTAB 2018) (citing Stone Lion Capital
Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d. at 1325, 110 USPQ2d at 1163), aff’d per curiam, 777 F.
App’x 516, 2019 BL 375518 (Fed. Cir. 2019).
Other Factors & Principles
Lack of Actual Confusion Not Dispositive. Applicant notes that "there is no evidence of actual
confusion." Response, at 4. But "a showing of actual confusion is not necessary to establish a likelihood
of confusion.” In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017)
(quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1380
(Fed. Cir. 2002)); TMEP §1207.01(d)(ii). “[T]he relevant test is likelihood of confusion,
not actual confusion.” In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1309, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1053 (Fed.
Cir. 2018) (emphasis in original). “Uncorroborated statements of no known instances of actual
confusion ... are of little evidentiary value,” especially in ex parte examination. In re Majestic Distilling
Co., 315 F.3d 1311, 1317, 65 USPQ2d 1201, 1205 (Fed. Cir. 2003).
Fame. Applicant argues that "the Prior pending applications do not appear to be famous." Response, at
4. Even if there were evidence in the record supporting this (which there is not), lack of fame is not
significant to the issue of likelihood of confusion in ex parte examination. See In re Davey Prods. Pty
Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1204 (TTAB 2009) (citing In re Thomas, 79 USPQ2d 1021, 1027 n.11 (TTAB
2006)); TMEP §1207.01(d)(ix). Because the types of evidence bearing on the fame of a registered mark
include the volume of sales, advertising expenditures, and length of use of the mark, and such evidence
normally is not publicly available, examiners are not expected to submit evidence regarding the fame of
a cited registered mark in ex parte proceedings. TMEP §1207.01(d)(ix); see In re Mr. Recipe, LLC, 118
USPQ2d 1084, 1086 (TTAB 2016) (citing In re Thomas, 79 USPQ2d at 1027 n.11). When no evidence
of fame has been provided, this du Pont factor is usually treated as neutral. See In re Mr. Recipe, LLC,
118 USPQ2d at 1086. Thus, as here, this factor is considered neutral for purposes of determining
likelihood of confusion.
Evidentiary Objection: Third-Party Registrations. Applicant's first response referenced various
other registrations but does actually introduce those registrations into the record. In re Peace Love
World Live, LLC, 127 USPQ2d 1400, 1405 n.17 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re 1st USA Realty Prof’ls, 84
USPQ2d 1581, 1583 (TTAB 2007); In re Duofold Inc., 184 USPQ 638, 640 (TTAB 1974)); TBMP
§1208.02; TMEP §710.03. To make a registration part of the record, an applicant must submit a copy
of the registration—or the complete electronic equivalent from the USPTO’s systems—prior to any
appeal. In re Star Belly Stitcher, Inc., 107 USPQ2d 2059, 2064 (TTAB 2013); TBMP §1208.02; TMEP
§710.03. Merely referencing search results is not sufficient, and these registrations need not be
considered. But even if they were, that would not change the outcome, as they are irrelevant to this
likelihood of confusion determination as detailed above.
Evidentiary Objection: Screenshots & Links. Applicant’s responses also include inline screenshots,
links, and webpages without access dates. E.g., First Response, at 5-6, 9-10; Second Response, at 14-
15. But applicant has not properly introduced any underlying websites into the record, so the Office
objects to any use of this evidence. Providing only a screenshot or link is not sufficient to introduce the
underlying website into the record. See In re ADCO Indus. – Techs., L.P., 2020 USPQ2d 53786, at *2
(TTAB 2020) (citing In re Olin, 124 USPQ2d 1327, 1331 n.15 (TTAB 2017); In re HSB Solomon
Assocs., LLC, 102 USPQ2d 1269, 1274 (TTAB 2012); TBMP §1208.03); TMEP §710.01(b). To
properly introduce websites into the record, an applicant must provide: (1) a saved copy of each
website; (2) the date it accessed the website; and (3) the complete URL of the website. See In re ICoat
Co., LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1730, 1733 (TTAB 2018); TBMP §1208.03; TMEP §710.01(b). Since
applicant's screenshots and links do not properly introduce any websites into the record, any underlying
websites associated with those screenshots and links need not be considered. Even if they were,
however, that would impact the analysis above or change the outcome.
Any Doubt Resolved in Favor of Registrants. The overriding concern is not only to prevent buyer
confusion as to the source of the services, but to protect registrants from adverse commercial impact
due to use of a similar mark by a newcomer. See In re Shell Oil Co., 992 F.2d 1204, 1208, 26 USPQ2d
1687, 1690 (Fed. Cir. 1993). Therefore, any doubt regarding a likelihood of confusion determination is
resolved in favor of the registrants. TMEP §1207.01(d)(i); see Hewlett-Packard Co. v. Packard Press,
Inc., 281 F.3d 1261, 1265, 62 USPQ2d 1001, 1003 (Fed. Cir. 2002); In re Hyper Shoppes (Ohio), Inc.,
837 F.2d 463, 464-65, 6 USPQ2d 1025, 1026 (Fed. Cir. 1988).
Conclusion
Applicant’s mark and the registered marks have highly similar appearances, sounds, and commercial
impressions, and they cover closely related services. Accordingly, there is a likelihood of consumer
confusion between these marks, so Section 2(d) bars registration of applicant’s mark.
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration.
ADVISORY: PRIOR-FILED APPLICATIONS
The filing dates of pending U.S. Application Serial Nos. 87982158 and 87951181 precede applicant’s
filing date. See previously attached applications. If either of those marks registers, applicant’s mark
may be refused registration under Section 2(d) because of a likelihood of confusion between the two
marks. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); 37 C.F.R. §2.83; TMEP §§1208. Accordingly, after receiving
applicant's response, the Office may suspend action on this application until both marks in the earlier-
filed applications register or abandon.
In response to this letter, applicant may present arguments in support of registration by addressing the
issue of the potential conflict between applicant’s mark and the marks in these applications. Applicant’s
election not to submit arguments at this time in no way limits applicant’s right to address this issue later
if a refusal under Section 2(d) issues
completion:
U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97329268


MARK: NEW YORK PREMIUM OUTLET


Amended Goods and services
Class 035
On-line retail store services featuring a wide variety of consumer goods of others; On-line retail store services featuring bags, wallets, clothing, jewelry, shoes, t-shirts, jackets, hoodies, sportswear; the foregoing excluding gift cards

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited Prior pending U.S. Application Serial Nos. 87982158 (LOS ANGELES PREMIUM OUTLETS with a disclaimer for "LOS ANGELES" AND "OUTLETS"), 87951181 (LOS ANGELES PREMIUM OUTLETS with a disclaimer for "LOS ANGELES" AND "OUTLETS")  as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

Prior pending Application 87982158  is for “Business management services in connection with retail shopping centers; promoting the goods and services of others by means of operating retail shopping centers, namely, operating shopping facilities providing access to the retail stores of others; advertising and marketing services; digital marketing services; promoting the goods and services of others by means of on-line and in-person marketing of gift cards redeemable for the purchase of the goods and services of others; promoting the goods and services of others by means of sponsorship relationships and strategic alliances; on-line retail store services in the field of gift cards “ in class 035, “Real estate management and leasing of retail shopping center space; retail shopping center services, namely, rental of shopping center space” in class 036 and  “Real estate development of retail shopping centers, namely, the planning and management of the construction of retail shopping venues “ in class 037.

Prior pending Application 87951181 is for “Magnetically encoded gift cards; magnetically encoded stored value cards “ in class 009 and “Retail shopping center services, namely, the hosting and conducting of entertainment events at retail shopping venues, namely, fashion shows, musical performances, live video game tournaments, live appearances by costumed characters for children, and live holiday dance and music performances “ in class 041.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
The cited applications are for LOS ANGELES PREMIUM OUTLETS, with "LOS ANGELES" AND "OUTLETS" disclaimed. There is a distinctiveness limitation as to “"PREMIUM OUTLETS" wherein “OUTLETS”, which clearly describes sales locations, is disclaimed.

“PREMIUM” is generic for quality of the products, and hence cannot benefit from a claim of acquired distinctiveness. 

From TMEP §1209.01:
Marks that are merely descriptive of the goods or services may not be registered on the Principal Register absent a showing of acquired distinctiveness under 15 U.S.C. §1052(f). See TMEP §1209.01(b) regarding merely descriptive marks, and TMEP §§1212–1212.10 regarding acquired distinctiveness. Merely descriptive marks may be registrable on the Supplemental Register in applications under §1 or §44 of the Trademark Act. 15 U.S.C. §1091. 					
Matter that is generic for the goods or services is not registrable on either the Principal or the Supplemental Register under any circumstances. See TMEP §§1209.01(c)–(c)(iii). 	

Typically, more evidence is required where a mark is so highly descriptive that purchasers seeing the matter in relation to the named goods or services would be less likely to believe that it indicates source in any one party. See Royal Crown Co. v. Coca-Cola Co., 892 F.3d 1358, 127 USPQ2d 1041, 1047 (Fed. Cir. 2018); In re Steelbuilding.com, 415 F.3d at 1300, 75 USPQ2d at 1424 (citing In re Bongrain Int’l (Am.) Corp., 894 F.2d 1316, 1318, 13 USPQ2d 1727, 1729 (Fed. Cir. 1990)); City of London Distillery, Ltd. v. Hayman Grp. Ltd., 2020 USPQ2d 11487, at *16 (TTAB 2020) (quoting In re Greenliant Sys. Ltd., 97 USPQ2d 1078, 1085 (TTAB 2010)); Alcatraz Media, Inc. v. Chesapeake Marine Tours Inc., 107 USPQ2d 1750, 1767 (TTAB 2013); In re Seaman & Assocs., Inc., 1 USPQ2d 1657, 1659 (TTAB 1986); In re Packaging Specialists, Inc., 221 USPQ 917, 919 (TTAB 1984). See also Real Foods Pty. v. Frito-Lay N. Am., 128 USPQ2d 1370, 1378 (Fed. Cir. 2018) ("while evidence of substantially exclusive and continuous use may be sufficient to prove a prima facie case of acquired distinctiveness, this is not always the case. . . . ‘Particularly for a mark that is . . . highly descriptive like [Real Foods’ proposed marks], the [TTAB] was within its discretion not to accept [Real Foods’] alleged five years of substantially exclusive and continuous use as prima facie evidence of acquired distinctiveness.’") (internal citations omitted);

Similarly, PREMIUM in respect of retail shops has not been exclusive (see attached evidence from other providers) and would also require more evidence as the name PREMIUM is descriptive of the quality of the products.

Furthermore, LOS ANGELES and NEW YORK are both descriptive of locations, but they are still parts of the respective marks and appear differently. Moreover, LOS ANGELES and NEW YORK have different connotations due to New York’s more finance centered history  and as a fashion capital, compared with LOS ANGELES’s history associated with filmmaking.				
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Prior pending Application 87982158  is for “Business management services in connection with retail shopping centers; promoting the goods and services of others by means of operating retail shopping centers, namely, operating shopping facilities providing access to the retail stores of others; advertising and marketing services; digital marketing services; promoting the goods and services of others by means of on-line and in-person marketing of gift cards redeemable for the purchase of the goods and services of others; promoting the goods and services of others by means of sponsorship relationships and strategic alliances; on-line retail store services in the field of gift cards “ in class 035, “Real estate management and leasing of retail shopping center space; retail shopping center services, namely, rental of shopping center space” in class 036 and  “Real estate development of retail shopping centers, namely, the planning and management of the construction of retail shopping venues “ in class 037.

Prior pending Application 87951181 is for “Magnetically encoded gift cards; magnetically encoded stored value cards “ in class 009 and “Retail shopping center services, namely, the hosting and conducting of entertainment events at retail shopping venues, namely, fashion shows, musical performances, live video game tournaments, live appearances by costumed characters for children, and live holiday dance and music performances “ in class 041.

Prior pending Applicant’s services for 87982158 are in class 035 and 037 for business management and planning and management of shopping centers. These are targeted towards the owners of the shopping centers, sophisticated professionals, who need these services, rather than consumers (like Applicant’s online retail services). Applicant has excluded gift cards from the goods sold in order to reduce the likelihood of confusion.

In terms of 87951181, Prior pending is for shopping center services which are large physical locations for retail. Applicant only provides online retail  services, which would be used by a consumer at home or on a mobile device, rather than a physical location like a shopping center. The services do not overlap and are directed mainly at different groups of consumers. 
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Prior pending applications do not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Prior pending marks. 


Objection based on Primarily Geographically Descriptive 2(e)(2)

Examiner objects to the Application as Primarily Geographically Descriptive under 2(e)(2).  Under 12010.01(a) of TMEP:
To establish a prima facie case for refusal to register a mark as primarily geographically descriptive, the examining attorney must show that:
(1) the primary significance of the mark is a generally known geographic location (see TMEP §§1210.02–1210.02(b)(iv));
(2) the goods or services originate in the place identified in the mark (see TMEP §1210.03); and
(3) purchasers would be likely to believe that the goods or services originate in the geographic place identified in the mark (see TMEP §§1210.04–1210.04(d)). Note: If the mark is remote or obscure, the public is unlikely to make a goods/place or services/place association (see TMEP §1210.04(c)).
With respect to part 1 of the test, under TMEP 1210.02(a) “vague geographic terms (e.g. , "Global," "National," "International," or "World") are not considered to be primarily geographic, though they may be merely descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive under §2(e)(1). See TMEP §1209.03(o).”
The presence of PREMIUM OUTLETS in the name avoids the identification of the mark as primarily geographically descriptive. There is also a connotation of NEW YORK as a sophisticated fashion and financial capital.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the following
mark(s):
AQUARIUS, in standard characters, for "Surface pumping systems for use in oilfields, namely,
fluid pumping machines, mechanical and electrical seals, thrust chambers in the nature of thrust
chambers being parts of the machines, pipes being parts of fluid pumping machines, mechanical
discharge heads, and frames in the nature of steel frames on which the equipment is affixed;
Pumps for surface pumping applications in onshore and offshore oil and gas fields, namely, high
pressure pumps for use in surface or downhole fluid movement/injection pumps for disposal,
injection, and treatment of fluids in, or from, oil and gas wells; and high pressure pumps for use
in industrial operations, namely, pumps for fluid transfer between equipment in industrial
facilities" in Class 7 (U.S. Registration No. 5897825)
•
AQUARIUS, in standard characters, for "Current generators; aeronautical engines; linear motors;
pistons being parts of machines; pistons being parts of machines engines; automotive engine
blocks; mechanical engine parts for land vehicles; high-frequency motor spindles with high
frequency electric converters and power supply units" in Class 7 (U.S. Registration No. 5878409)
•
Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP §§1207.01 et seq. See the attached
registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
1. Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Applicant's Mark: WASSERMANN, with designs
Registrant's Mark: AQUARIUS, in standard characters (U.S. Registration Nos. 5897825 and 5878409)
Under the doctrine of foreign equivalents, a mark in a common, modern foreign language and a mark
that is its English equivalent may be held confusingly similar. TMEP §1207.01(b)(vi); see, e.g., In re
Aquamar, Inc., 115 USPQ2d 1122, 1127-28 (TTAB 2015); In re Thomas, 79 USPQ2d 1021, 1025
(TTAB 2006). Consequently, marks comprised of foreign wording are translated into English to
determine similarity in meaning and connotation with English word marks. See Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v.
Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Maison Fondee en 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1377, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1696
(Fed. Cir. 2005). Equivalence in meaning and connotation may be sufficient to find such marks
confusingly similar. See In re Aquamar, Inc., 115 USPQ2d at 1127-28; In re Thomas, 79 USPQ2d at
1025.
Applicant’s mark is in German, which is a common, modern language in the United States. See In re
Jos. Schlitz Brewing Co., 223 USPQ 45 (TTAB 1983) (German). See attached,
or https://translate.google.com/?sl=auto&tl=en&text=wassermann&op=translate
The doctrine is applied when “the ordinary American purchaser” would “stop and translate” the foreign
term into its English equivalent. Palm Bay, 396 F.3d at 1377, 73 USPQ2d at 1696 (quoting In re Pan
Tex Hotel Corp., 190 USPQ 109, 110 (TTAB 1976)); TMEP §1207.01(b)(vi)(A). The ordinary
American purchaser includes those proficient in the foreign language. In re Spirits Int’l, N.V., 563 F.3d
1347, 1352, 90 USPQ2d 1489, 1492 (Fed. Cir. 2009); see In re Thomas, 79 USPQ2d at 1024.
In this case, the ordinary American purchaser would likely stop and translate the mark because the
German language is a common, modern language spoken by an appreciable number of consumers in
the United States.
Furthermore, the applicant included design elements.
When evaluating a composite mark consisting of words and a design, the word portion is normally
accorded greater weight because it is likely to make a greater impression upon purchasers, be
remembered by them, and be used by them to refer to or request the goods and/or services. In re
Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting CBS Inc. v.
Morrow, 708 F.2d 1579, 1581-82, 218 USPQ 198, 200 (Fed. Cir. 1983)); Made in Nature, LLC v.
Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *41 (TTAB 2022) (quoting Sabhnani v. Mirage Brands, LLC,
2021 USPQ2d 1241, at *31 (TTAB 2021)); TMEP §1207.01(c)(ii). Thus, although marks must be
compared in their entireties, the word portion is often considered the dominant feature and is accorded
greater weight in determining whether marks are confusingly similar, even where the word portion has
been disclaimed. In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d at 1366-67, 101 USPQ2d at 1911 (citing Giant Food, Inc.
v. Nation’s Foodservice, Inc., 710 F.2d 1565, 1570-71, 218 USPQ2d 390, 395 (Fed. Cir. 1983)).
Here, even though the applicant includes the man and bands designs, the inclusion of the designs do not
alter the overall commercial impression between the marks because purchasers are more likely to be
impressed by the wording of the mark. Thus, the more dominant feature is the wording, which is
afforded greater weight in determining whether the marks are confusingly similar. Thus, the
presentation of the applied-for mark, in stylized font with the inclusion of the design, does not diminish
its similarity to the registered mark or obviate a likelihood of confusion finding.
Therefore, the marks are confusingly similar.
2. Relatedness of the Goods
Applicant's goods:
Class 7: Alternators; Automotive parts, namely, turbocharger systems; Centrifugal machines;
Industrial engines; Injectors for engines; Pumps as parts of machines, motors and engines; Pumps
for machines; Soldering apparatus, electric; Valves being parts of machines; Valves for pumps
•
Registrant's goods:
Class 7: Surface pumping systems for use in oilfields, namely, fluid pumping machines,
mechanical and electrical seals, thrust chambers in the nature of thrust chambers being parts of
the machines, pipes being parts of fluid pumping machines, mechanical discharge heads, and
frames in the nature of steel frames on which the equipment is affixed; Pumps for surface
pumping applications in onshore and offshore oil and gas fields, namely, high pressure pumps for
use in surface or downhole fluid movement/injection pumps for disposal, injection, and treatment
of fluids in, or from, oil and gas wells; and high pressure pumps for use in industrial operations,
namely, pumps for fluid transfer between equipment in industrial facilities (U.S. Registration No.
5897825)
•
Class 7: Current generators; aeronautical engines; linear motors; pistons being parts of machines;
pistons being parts of machines engines; automotive engine blocks; mechanical engine parts for
land vehicles; high-frequency motor spindles with high frequency electric converters and power
supply units (U.S. Registration No. 5878409)
•
The goods are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related, or travel in the
same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369-71, 101
USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1165,
64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
Determining likelihood of confusion is based on the description of the goods stated in the application
and registration at issue, not on extrinsic evidence of actual use. [emphasis added] See In re Detroit
Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1307, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1052 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1325, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1749 (Fed. Cir. 2017)).
In this case, the application use(s) broad wording to describe goods, such as "Industrial machines;
Pumps for machines; Pumps as parts of machines, motors and engines", which presumably
encompasses all goods of the type described, including registrant(s)’s more narrow goods, such as
"aeronautical engines; Pumps for surface pumping applications in onshore and offshore oil and gas
fields, namely, high pressure pumps for use in surface or downhole fluid movement/injection pumps for
disposal, injection, and treatment of fluids in, or from, oil and gas wells; and high pressure pumps for
use in industrial operations, namely, pumps for fluid transfer between equipment in industrial
facilities". See, e.g., Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB
2022); In re Solid State Design Inc., 125 USPQ2d 1409, 1412-15 (TTAB 2018); Sw. Mgmt., Inc. v.
Ocinomled, Ltd., 115 USPQ2d 1007, 1025 (TTAB 2015). Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods are
legally identical. See, e.g., In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 127 USPQ2d 1627, 1629 (TTAB 2018) (citing
Tuxedo Monopoly, Inc. v. Gen. Mills Fun Grp., Inc., 648 F.2d 1335, 1336, 209 USPQ 986, 988
(C.C.P.A. 1981); Inter IKEA Sys. B.V. v. Akea, LLC, 110 USPQ2d 1734, 1745 (TTAB 2014); Baseball
Am. Inc. v. Powerplay Sports Ltd., 71 USPQ2d 1844, 1847 n.9 (TTAB 2004)).
Additionally, the goods and/or services of the parties have no restrictions as to nature, type, channels of
trade, or classes of purchasers and are “presumed to travel in the same channels of trade to the same
class of purchasers.” In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir.
2012) (quoting Hewlett-Packard Co. v. Packard Press, Inc., 281 F.3d 1261, 1268, 62 USPQ2d 1001,
1005 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *49. Thus,
applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are related.
Therefore, applicant's goods and registrant's goods are considered related for likelihood of confusion
purposes.
The marks create the same commercial impression and the goods are commercially related and are
likely to be encountered together in the marketplace by consumers. Accordingly, consumers are likely
to be confused and mistakenly believe that the products originate from a common source. Therefore,
registration must be refused. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. § 1052(d); see TMEP
§§ 1207.01 et seq.

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97531892


MARK: WASSERMANN


Amended Goods and services
Class 007
Centrifugal machines; Soldering apparatus, electric; 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited AQUARIUS, in standard characters (U.S. Registration Nos. 5897825 and 5878409) as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

The cited marks are for:
U.S. Registration No. 5897825
Class 7: Surface pumping systems for use in oilfields, namely, fluid pumping machines,
mechanical and electrical seals, thrust chambers in the nature of thrust chambers being parts of the machines, pipes being parts of fluid pumping machines, mechanical discharge heads, and frames in the nature of steel frames on which the equipment is affixed; Pumps for surface pumping applications in onshore and offshore oil and gas fields, namely, high pressure pumps for use in surface or downhole fluid movement/injection pumps for disposal, injection, and treatment of fluids in, or from, oil and gas wells; and high pressure pumps for use in industrial operations,
namely, pumps for fluid transfer between equipment in industrial facilities 

U.S. Registration No. 5878409
Class 7: Current generators; aeronautical engines; linear motors; pistons being parts of machines; pistons being parts of machines engines; automotive engine blocks; mechanical engine parts for land vehicles; high-frequency motor spindles with high frequency electric converters and power supply units 

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
Registration is for AQUARIUS which is a zodiac or horoscope sign for birthdays in February and relates to a water carrier Ganymede. 

Application is for WASSERMANN which is a surname (see attached) as well as a type of reaction or test “complement-fixing reaction that occurs in a positive complement-fixation test for syphilis.” It is also a lake in Minnesota. While it is the German name for Aquarius, translating into Water-Man, that is not the main consumer impression for Americans, rather it is a frequent surname, with many famous examples.

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Registration 5897825 is for pumping systems used industrially and in oilfields. Oilfield and industrial equipment is generally not mobile, and the uses are different. Mainly, however, purchasers of industrial and oilfield equipment are companies that work in that space - they are sophisticated purchasers who are not easily confused with similar trademarks.

Class 7: Surface pumping systems for use in oilfields, namely, fluid pumping machines,
mechanical and electrical seals, thrust chambers in the nature of thrust chambers being parts of the machines, pipes being parts of fluid pumping machines, mechanical discharge heads, and frames in the nature of steel frames on which the equipment is affixed; Pumps for surface pumping applications in onshore and offshore oil and gas fields, namely, high pressure pumps for use in surface or downhole fluid movement/injection pumps for disposal, injection, and treatment of fluids in, or from, oil and gas wells; and high pressure pumps for use in industrial operations,
namely, pumps for fluid transfer between equipment in industrial facilities 

U.S. Registration No. 5878409 is for mechanical engine parts for vehicles
Class 7: Current generators; aeronautical engines; linear motors; pistons being parts of machines; pistons being parts of machines engines; automotive engine blocks; mechanical engine parts for land vehicles; high-frequency motor spindles with high frequency electric converters and power supply units.

Some of applicant’s goods have no or very little relation to the Registrant’s 5878409  goods, for example “Centrifugal machines; Soldering apparatus, electric.” Applicant has narrowed to these goods to avoid any likelihood of confusion.

The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 4288288. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
The overriding concern is not only to prevent buyer confusion as to the source of the goods and/or
services, but to protect the registrant from adverse commercial impact due to use of a similar mark by a
newcomer. See In re Shell Oil Co., 992 F.2d 1204, 1208, 26 USPQ2d 1687, 1690 (Fed. Cir. 1993).
Therefore, any doubt regarding a likelihood of confusion determination is resolved in favor of the
registrant. TMEP §1207.01(d)(i); see Hewlett-Packard Co. v. Packard Press, Inc., 281 F.3d 1261,
1265, 62 USPQ2d 1001, 1003 (Fed. Cir. 2002); In re Hyper Shoppes (Ohio), Inc., 837 F.2d 463, 464-
65, 6 USPQ2d 1025, 1026 (Fed. Cir. 1988).
Comparison of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
In the instant case, the applicant’s mark “KENDOO” is highly similar to the registrant’s mark
“KENDO UI”. The only difference between the marks is that the applicant added a second letter "O" to
the wording "KENDO" in the registered mark and deleted the descriptive wording "UI" from the
registered mark.
As noted above, the applicant added a second letter "O" to the wording "KENDO" in the registered
mark. The wording "KENDO" and "KENDOO" are essentially phonetic equivalents and thus sound
similar. Similarity in sound alone may be sufficient to support a finding that the compared marks are
confusingly similar. In re 1st USA Realty Prof’ls, Inc., 84 USPQ2d 1581, 1586 (TTAB 2007) (citing
Krim-Ko Corp. v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co., 390 F.2d 728, 732, 156 USPQ 523, 526 (C.C.P.A. 1968));
TMEP §1207.01(b)(iv).
Although marks are compared in their entireties, one feature of a mark may be more significant or
dominant in creating a commercial impression. See In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101
USPQ2d 1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir. 2012); In re Nat’l Data Corp., 753 F.2d 1056, 1058, 224 USPQ 749,
751 (Fed. Cir. 1985); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii). Disclaimed matter that is descriptive of or
generic for a party’s goods and/or services is typically less significant or less dominant when
comparing marks. See In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1050 (Fed.
Cir. 2018) (citing In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1407, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533-34 (Fed. Cir.
1997)); Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *41 (TTAB 2022); TMEP
§1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii). In this case, the registrant disclaimed the merely descriptive wording "UI"
apart from the mark as show, thus making the wording "KENDO" more significant or dominant in
creating a commercial impression.
Comparison of the Goods & Services
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i).
The applicant’s goods in International Class 9 for “Batteries; Earphones; Smartphones; Battery
chargers; Walkie-talkies” are closely related to the registrant’s goods in International Class 9 for
“Computer software development tools; computer software for testing computer software; computer
software, namely, software development tools for the creation of mobile internet applications and client
interfaces; web site development software” and services in International Class 42 for "Technical
support services, namely, troubleshooting of problems relating to computer software; providing
technical support and troubleshooting information via the Internet relating to fixing computer software
problems".
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of website screenshots from Apple, Samsung, and Android,
establishes that the same entity commonly manufactures, produces, or provides the relevant goods
and/or services and markets the goods and/or services under the same mark, the relevant goods and/or
services are sold or provided through the same trade channels and used by the same classes of
consumers in the same fields of use, and the goods and/or services are similar or complementary in
terms of purpose or function. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are considered
related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198,
1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB
2009).
Purchasers of applicant’s goods could mistakenly assume such goods were produced by registrant, or
that applicant and registrant are related in some way. Accordingly, since the marks are confusingly
similar and the goods and services are closely related, there is a likelihood of confusion and registration
must be refused under Section 2(d) of the Trademark Act.
Although the trademark examining attorney has refused registration, applicant may respond to the
refusal to register by submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration.

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97614049


MARK: KENDOO 


Amended Goods and services
Class 009
Batteries; Earphones; Smartphones; Battery chargers; Walkie-talkies  

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 4288288 KENDO UI for “Computer software development tools; computer software for testing computer software; computer software, namely, software development tools for the creation of mobile internet applications and client interfaces; web site development software “ in class 009 and “Technical support services, namely, troubleshooting of problems relating to computer software; providing technical support and troubleshooting information via the Internet relating to fixing computer software problems “ in class 042 as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d. "UI" is disclaimed as descriptive of the services.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
Registration is for KENDO UI, with UI disclaimed (it is descriptive of “user interface” aspects of the goods/services). KENDO is a martial art that involves fighting with swords (see attached Wikipedia article). KENDOO has no meaning, and is certainly no synonymous with KENDO as it appears and looks different. The consumer impression of KENDO with its deep connection to Japanese samurai culture has a different connotation from the fanciful term KENDOO which has no meaning. Further, UI in the Registration clearly stands for “user interface,” which indicates to a consumer that the Registration has to do with user interfaces, which it does in both class 009 and 042.

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Registration KENDO UI for “Computer software development tools; computer software for testing computer software; computer software, namely, software development tools for the creation of mobile internet applications and client interfaces; web site development software “ in class 009 and “Technical support services, namely, troubleshooting of problems relating to computer software; providing technical support and troubleshooting information via the Internet relating to fixing computer software problems “ in class 042. Especially the goods in class 009 appear for use by professionals (“software development tools”) who are sophisticated consumers; these products would not be used by lay consumers. 

The application is for physical consumer electronics like “Batteries; Earphones; Smartphones; Battery chargers; Walkie-talkies.” The channels of trade are also different. Increasingly, software is only sold by download and use over the cloud, while consumer products are physical in nature and must be purchased in a physical store or mailed to the consumer. 
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration Nos. 1498703, 1915089, 1915090, and 2899648. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15
U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP §§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registrations.
The applied-for mark is I.N.C. International Concepts (in standard character form) for "Handbags;
Beach bags; Clutch bags; Leather bags; Tote bags; Travelling bags" in International Class 18.
The registered marks are owned by the same registrant. Registration No. 1498703 is I.N.C.
INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS
(in stylized form) for "MEN'S APPAREL; NAMELY, KNIT TOPS, SWEATERS, WOVEN SHIRTS,
JACKETS, BOTTOMS, SWIMWEAR" in International Class 25.
Registration No. 1915089 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS (in typed form) for "men's
apparel, namely knit tops, sweaters, woven shirts, jackets, bottoms and swimwear" in International
Class 25.
Registration No. 1915090 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS (in typed form) for "women's
apparel, namely pants, tops, jackets, sweaters and socks" in International Class 25.
Registration No. 2899648 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS WOMAN (in typed form) for
"Women's clothing, namely, jackets, blazers, blouses, shirts, pants, dresses, skirts, knit tops, sweaters,
down jackets, scarves, sleepwear, panties, bras, slips, hosiery, socks, belts" in International Class 25.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Comparison of the Marks
Registration Nos. 1915089 and 1915090
In a likelihood of confusion determination, the marks in their entireties are compared for similarities in
appearance, sound, connotation, and commercial impression. In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315,
1323, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1748 (Fed. Cir. 2017); Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP,
746 F.3d 1317, 1321, 110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve
Clicquot Ponsardin Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir.
2005)); In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A.
1973); TMEP §1207.01(b)-(b)(v).
In the present case, applicant’s mark is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS and registrant’s mark
is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS. These marks are identical in appearance, sound, and
meaning, “and have the potential to be used . . . in exactly the same manner.” In re i.am.symbolic, llc,
116 USPQ2d 1406, 1411 (TTAB 2015), aff’d, 866 F.3d 1315, 123 USPQ2d 1744 (Fed. Cir. 2017).
Additionally, because they are identical, these marks are likely to engender the same connotation and
overall commercial impression when considered in connection with applicant’s and registrant’s
respective goods. Id.
Therefore, the marks are confusingly similar.
Registration Nos. 1498703 and 2899648
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
With respect to Registration No. 2899648, although marks are compared in their entireties, one feature
of a mark may be more significant or dominant in creating a commercial impression. See In re Detroit
Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1050 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re Dixie Rests.,
105 F.3d 1405, 1407, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533-34 (Fed. Cir. 1997)); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii).
Matter that is descriptive of or generic for a party’s goods and/or services is typically less significant or
less dominant in relation to other wording in a mark. See Anheuser-Busch, LLC v. Innvopak Sys. Pty
Ltd., 115 USPQ2d 1816, 1824-25 (TTAB 2015) (citing In re Chatam Int’l Inc., 380 F.3d 1340, 1342-
43, 71 USPQ2d 1944, 1946 (Fed. Cir. 2004)).
In the present case, the record shows that the wording WOMAN in the registered mark is merely
descriptive of or generic for the registrant’s goods. Thus, this wording is less significant in terms of
affecting the mark’s commercial impression, and renders the wording I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL
CONCEPTS the more dominant element of the mark.
The applied-for and registered marks share the identical wording I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL
CONCEPTS. Applicant has merely removed the descriptive and/or generic matter WOMAN from the
wording in the mark in Registration No. 2899648. Although applicant’s mark does not contain the
entirety of the registered mark, applicant’s mark is likely to appear to prospective purchasers as a
shortened form of registrant’s mark. See In re Mighty Leaf Tea, 601 F.3d 1342, 1348, 94 USPQ2d
1257, 1260 (Fed. Cir. 2010) (quoting United States Shoe Corp., 229 USPQ 707, 709 (TTAB 1985)).
Thus, merely omitting some of the wording from a registered mark may not overcome a likelihood of
confusion. See In re Mighty Leaf Tea, 601 F.3d 1342, 94 USPQ2d 1257; In re Optica Int’l, 196 USPQ
775, 778 (TTAB 1977); TMEP §1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii). In this case, applicant’s mark does not create a
distinct commercial impression from the registered mark because it contains some of the wording in the
registered mark and does not add any wording that would distinguish it from that mark. Furthermore,
the stylization of the mark in Registration No. 1498703 does not obviate the similarity between the
marks. The applied-for mark is in standard character form and may be displayed in any manner
including identical to the registered mark. A mark in typed or standard characters may be displayed in
any lettering style; the rights reside in the wording or other literal element and not in any particular
display or rendition. See In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1363, 101 USPQ2d 1905, 1909 (Fed. Cir.
2012); In re Mighty Leaf Tea, 601 F.3d 1342, 1348, 94 USPQ2d 1257, 1260 (Fed. Cir. 2010); 37 C.F.R.
§2.52(a); TMEP §1207.01(c)(iii). Thus, a mark presented in stylized characters and/or with a design
element generally will not avoid likelihood of confusion with a mark in typed or standard characters
because the word portion could be presented in the same manner of display. See, e.g., In re Viterra Inc.,
671 F.3d at 1363, 101 USPQ2d at 1909; Squirtco v. Tomy Corp., 697 F.2d 1038, 1041, 216 USPQ 937,
939 (Fed. Cir. 1983) (stating that “the argument concerning a difference in type style is not viable
where one party asserts rights in no particular display”).
Based on the foregoing, the applicant’s applied-for and registrant’s marks are sufficiently similar to
find a likelihood of confusion.
Comparison of the Goods
The compared goods need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of confusion. See
On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475 (Fed. Cir.
2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000); TMEP
§1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances surrounding
their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods and/or services]
emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369,
101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83 USPQ2d 1715, 1724
(TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i).
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of handbags, clutch bags, tote bags, women's clothing,
namely, jackets, blazers, blouses, shirts, pants, dresses, skirts, sweaters, scarves, sleepwear, panties,
bras, socks, belts, men's apparel, namely, sweaters, jackets, bottoms and swimwear from macys.com,
toryburch.com, usa.tommy.com, establishes that the same entity commonly manufactures, produces, or
provides the relevant goods and markets the goods under the same mark. The evidence also establishes
that the relevant goods are sold or provided through the same trade channels and used by the same
classes of consumers in the same fields of use. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods are considered
related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198,
1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB
2009).
Based on the analysis above, applicant’s and registrant’s goods are related.
Because applicant’s and registrant’s marks are similar and the goods and/or services are related, there is
a likelihood of confusion and applicant’s applied-for mark must be refused under Section 2(d) of the
Lanham Act.
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal(s) by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration
