U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97888724


MARK: I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS 


Amended Goods and services
Class 018
Beach bags; 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration Nos. 1498703, 1915089, 1915090, and 2899648 as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

Registration No. 1498703 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS (in stylized form) for "MEN'S APPAREL; NAMELY, KNIT TOPS, SWEATERS, WOVEN SHIRTS, JACKETS, BOTTOMS, SWIMWEAR" in International Class 25.

Registration No. 1915089 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS (in typed form) for "men's
apparel, namely knit tops, sweaters, woven shirts, jackets, bottoms and swimwear" in International Class 25.

Registration No. 1915090 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS (in typed form) for "women's apparel, namely pants, tops, jackets, sweaters and socks" in International Class 25.

Registration No. 2899648 is I.N.C. INTERNATIONAL CONCEPTS WOMAN (in typed form) for "Women's clothing, namely, jackets, blazers, blouses, shirts, pants, dresses, skirts, knit tops, sweaters, down jackets, scarves, sleepwear, panties, bras, slips, hosiery, socks, belts" in International Class 25.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
Registration is I.N.C. International Concepts. “INC” is a short form for “incorporation” which a type of company organization. “International” also describes the company or the fashion styles of the Registration. “Concept” is a unifying idea for a product (see below). “I.N.C.” also appears to be an abbreviation for InterNational Concepts. The mark is therefore composed partially or entirely of descriptive elements.
 

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The Registration is for clothing of a variety of types, but not for beach bags. Beach bags (currently amended goods ID for the application) are waterproof or water resistant since the articles put therein are often wet, and the bag is designed not to grow mold or rot, for example.

Consumers do not expect clothing manufacturers to make beach bags. To take an example provided by the Examiner, on the Tommy Hilfiger site despite a huge variety of clothing and some bags, there are no beach bags. If a site like Tommy.com does not carry beach bags, it is submitted that a consumer  does not expect clothing manufacturers and companies to also make beach bags.


 
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 6367390. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
SIMILARITY OF THE MARKS
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s standard character mark is UCHE ORGANICS. Registrant's mark is UCHE with a
design. The dominant literal portion of the marks is UCHE. Marks may be confusingly similar in
appearance where similar terms or phrases or similar parts of terms or phrases appear in the compared
marks and create a similar overall commercial impression. See Crocker Nat’l Bank v. Canadian
Imperial Bank of Commerce, 228 USPQ 689, 690-91 (TTAB 1986), aff’d sub nom. Canadian Imperial
Bank of Commerce v. Wells Fargo Bank, Nat’l Ass’n, 811 F.2d 1490, 1495, 1 USPQ2d 1813, 1817
(Fed. Cir. 1987) (holding COMMCASH and COMMUNICASH confusingly similar); In re Corning
Glass Works, 229 USPQ 65, 66 (TTAB 1985) (holding CONFIRM and CONFIRMCELLS confusingly
similar); In re Pellerin Milnor Corp., 221 USPQ 558, 560 (TTAB 1983) (holding MILTRON and
MILLTRONICS confusingly similar); TMEP §1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii).
Because the marks create the same commercial impression, they are confusingly similar.
RELATEDNESS OF THE GOODS AND/OR SERVICES
The goods and/or services are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related,
or travel in the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356,
1369-71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods are "Hair care creams; Hair butter; Hair conditioner; Hair creams; Hair curling
preparations; Hair detangler preparations; Hair lotion; Hair masks; Hair moisturizers; Hair nourishers;
Hair pomades; Hair products, namely, thickening control creams; Hair relaxing preparations; Hair
texturizers; Hair waving preparations; Cosmetic hair dressing preparations; Cosmetic preparations for
hair care; Leave-in hair conditioners; Non-medicated hair serums; Non-medicated hair treatment
preparations for cosmetic purposes; Non-medicated balm for hair; Preparations for setting
hair." Registrant’s goods are "Cosmetics, cosmetic preparations for skin care, non-medicated skin care
preparations, mask pack for cosmetic purposes, pore tightening mask packs for used as cosmetics, anti-
aging cosmetic preparations, anti-wrinkle creams, cream for whitening the skin, whitening essences,
namely, skin whitening preparations, serums for cosmetic purposes, functional cosmetics, natural
cosmetics, eye cream, skin lotions, non-medicated skin toners, hand cream, cleansing cream for
cosmetic purposes, make-up, cosmetic preparations for body care, cosmetics for massage." Both
parties provide cosmetic preparations. See applicant's goods at Uche Organics - #1 Best Natural Hair
Products - Paraben Free Products. See registrant's goods at Pure Whitenol Serum(Brightening,
Skincare, Blemish cure) - Reviresco Co.,Ltd. (kbiztrade.com). Consumers may mistakenly believe that
the goods of both parties originate from the same single source.
The trademark examining attorney has attached evidence from the USPTO’s X-Search database
consisting of a number of third-party marks registered for use in connection with the same or similar
goods and/or services as those of both applicant and registrant in this case. This evidence shows that the
goods and/or services listed therein, namely skin care and hair care preparations, are of a kind that may
emanate from a single source under a single mark. See In re I-Coat Co., 126 USPQ2d 1730, 1737
(TTAB 2018) (citing In re Infinity Broad. Corp., 60 USPQ2d 1214, 1217-18 (TTAB 2001); In re Albert
Trostel & Sons Co., 29 USPQ2d 1783, 1785-86 (TTAB 1993); In re Mucky Duck Mustard Co., 6
USPQ2d 1467, 1470 n.6 (TTAB 1988)); TMEP §1207.01(d)(iii). Applicant’s and registrant’s goods
are considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92
USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69,
1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Because the marks are confusingly similar and the goods are related, purchasers encountering the goods
are likely to believe, mistakenly, that they emanate from a common source. Accordingly, there is a
likelihood of confusion and registration is refused pursuant to Section 2(d) of the Trademark Act

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97437537


MARK: UCHE ORGANICS 


Amended Goods and services
Class 003
Hair care creams; Hair butter; Hair conditioner; Hair creams; Hair curling preparations; Hair detangler preparations; Hair lotion; Hair masks; Hair moisturizers; Hair nourishers; Hair pomades; Hair products, namely, thickening control creams; Hair relaxing preparations; Hair texturizers; Hair waving preparations; Cosmetic hair dressing preparations; Cosmetic preparations for hair care; Leave-in hair conditioners; Non-medicated hair serums; Non-medicated hair treatment preparations for cosmetic purposes; Non-medicated balm for hair; Preparations for setting hair, all of the foregoing being organic

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 6367390 UCHE for “Cosmetics, cosmetic preparations for skin care, non-medicated skin care preparations, mask pack for cosmetic purposes, pore tightening mask packs for used as cosmetics, anti-aging cosmetic preparations, anti-wrinkle creams, cream for whitening the skin, whitening essences, namely, skin whitening preparations, serums for cosmetic purposes, functional cosmetics, natural cosmetics, eye cream, skin lotions, non-medicated skin toners, hand cream, cleansing cream for cosmetic purposes, make-up, cosmetic preparations for body care, cosmetics for massage “ in class 003 as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.


The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
UCHE is a common Nigerian surname (see enclosed). Surnames in trademark law are generally non-registrable without a showing of acquired distinctiveness. From S.1211 of the TMEP:

The Trademark Act, in §2(e)(4), reflects the common law that exclusive rights in a surname per se cannot be established without evidence of long and exclusive use that changes its significance to the public from that of a surname to that of a mark for particular goods or services. The common law also recognizes that surnames are shared by more than one individual, each of whom may have an interest in using his surname in business; and, by the requirement for evidence of distinctiveness, the law, in effect, delays appropriation of exclusive rights in the name. In re Etablissements Darty et Fils, 759 F.2d 15, 17, 225 USPQ 652, 653 (Fed. Cir. 1985).
 

In this case, the distinctive design elements of the Registration which allowed it to register despite being a surname are not shared at all with the Application, which is merely in standard characters. 

The Applicant’s mark is not primarily a surname as it contains ORGANICS which indicates the products are organic. Organics also does not appear in surnames.  

The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The goods are different - the Registrant’s goods are for skin care while the Applicant’s are for hair care. They are sold for different purposes in different parts of a drug store or grocery store, for example, so the channels of trade are also somewhat different.
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 5825658. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Applicant has applied to register the mark JINDA in standard characters for “Pajamas; Shirts; Skirts;
Suits; Sweaters; Swimsuits; Trousers; Masquerade costumes; Swimming trunks; Tops as clothing” in
International Class 025.
Registrant’s mark is JINDA HOME FASHION with a design for “Bed sheets; Comforters; Curtains;
Cushion covers; Pillow cases; Pillow covers; Pillow shams; Bath linen; Bed linen and table linen;
Fabric table runners; Fitted bed sheets; Household linen; Pillowcases; Table linen.” in International
Class 024.
Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, JINDA, is confusingly similar to the registered mark, JINDA HOME
FASHION with a design.
The identical wording "JINDA" appears first in the applied-for mark as well as U.S. Registration No(s)
5825658. Consumers are generally more inclined to focus on the first word, prefix, or syllable in any
trademark or service mark. See Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Maison Fondee En
1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1372, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1692 (Fed. Cir. 2005) (finding similarity between
VEUVE ROYALE and two VEUVE CLICQUOT marks in part because “VEUVE . . . remains a
‘prominent feature’ as the first word in the mark and the first word to appear on the label”); Century 21
Real Estate Corp. v. Century Life of Am., 970 F.2d 874, 876, 23 USPQ2d 1698, 1700 (Fed Cir. 1992)
(finding similarity between CENTURY 21 and CENTURY LIFE OF AMERICA in part because
“consumers must first notice th[e] identical lead word”); see also In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d
1297, 1303, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1049 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (finding “the identity of the marks’ two initial
words is particularly significant because consumers typically notice those words first”). Thus, the
registrant’s mark is likely to engender the same connotation and overall commercial impression when
considered in connection with applicant’s and registrant’s respective goods and/or services. Id.
U.S. Registration No. 5825658 contain(s) design elements.When evaluating a composite mark
consisting of words and a design, the word portion is normally accorded greater weight because it is
likely to make a greater impression upon purchasers, be remembered by them, and be used by them to
refer to or request the goods and/or services. In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d
1905, 1908 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting CBS Inc. v. Morrow, 708 F.2d 1579, 1581-82, 218 USPQ 198,
200 (Fed. Cir. 1983)); Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *41 (TTAB
2022) (quoting Sabhnani v. Mirage Brands, LLC, 2021 USPQ2d 1241, at *31 (TTAB 2021)); TMEP
§1207.01(c)(ii). Thus, although marks must be compared in their entireties, the word portion is often
considered the dominant feature and is accorded greater weight in determining whether marks are
confusingly similar, even where the word portion has been disclaimed. In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d at
1366-67, 101 USPQ2d at 1911 (citing Giant Food, Inc. v. Nation’s Foodservice, Inc., 710 F.2d 1565,
1570-71, 218 USPQ2d 390, 395 (Fed. Cir. 1983)). In this case, the wording in U.S. Registration No(s).
5825658 is the more important feature of the mark. The mark(s) would not be further distinguished by
the additional design components since a consumer would reference the marks by the written word
portion.
The mark in U.S. Registration No. 5825658 is "JINDA HOME FASHION. The wording “HOME
FASHION” has been disclaimed for descriptiveness of the registered goods and/or services. Although
marks are compared in their entireties, one feature of a mark may be more significant or dominant in
creating a commercial impression. See In re Viterra Inc., 671 F.3d 1358, 1362, 101 USPQ2d 1905,
1908 (Fed. Cir. 2012); In re Nat’l Data Corp., 753 F.2d 1056, 1058, 224 USPQ 749, 751 (Fed. Cir.
1985); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii). Disclaimed matter that is descriptive of or generic for a party’s
goods and/or services is typically less significant or less dominant when comparing marks. See In re
Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1050 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re Dixie
Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1407, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533-34 (Fed. Cir. 1997)); Made in Nature, LLC
v. Pharmavite LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *41 (TTAB 2022); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii).
Therefore, the wording "HOME FASHION" is less significant in terms of affecting the mark’s overall
commercial impression and renders the wording “JINDA” the more dominant element of the mark.
The dominant wording "JINDA" in the applied-for mark and registrant’s mark creates a similar overall
commercial impression. Marks may be confusingly similar in appearance where similar terms or
phrases or similar parts of terms or phrases appear in the compared marks and create a similar overall
commercial impression. See Crocker Nat’l Bank v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, 228 USPQ
689, 690-91 (TTAB 1986), aff’d sub nom. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce v. Wells Fargo Bank,
Nat’l Ass’n, 811 F.2d 1490, 1495, 1 USPQ2d 1813, 1817 (Fed. Cir. 1987) (holding COMMCASH and
COMMUNICASH confusingly similar); In re Corning Glass Works, 229 USPQ 65, 66 (TTAB 1985)
(holding CONFIRM and CONFIRMCELLS confusingly similar); In re Pellerin Milnor Corp., 221
USPQ 558, 560 (TTAB 1983) (holding MILTRON and MILLTRONICS confusingly similar); TMEP
§1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii). Therefore, viewed as a whole, applicant’s mark is substantially similar in sound,
appearance, connotation, and commercial impression to the registrant's marks.
Because the marks look and sound similar and create the same commercial impression, the marks are
considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods and/or Services
The goods and/or services are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related,
or travel in the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356,
1369-71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods and/or services, “Pajamas; Shirts; Skirts; Suits; Sweaters; Swimsuits; Trousers;
Masquerade costumes; Swimming trunks; Tops as clothing,” are closely related to registrant’s goods
and/or services, “Bed sheets; Comforters; Curtains; Cushion covers; Pillow cases; Pillow covers;
Pillow shams; Bath linen; Bed linen and table linen; Fabric table runners; Fitted bed sheets; Household
linen; Pillowcases; Table linen.”
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of eddiebauer.com, ralphlauren.com, and zara.com,
establishes that the same entity commonly manufactures, produces, or provides the relevant goods
and/or services and markets the goods and/or services under the same mark. Thus, applicant’s and
registrant’s goods and/or services are considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g.,
In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp.,
91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Accordingly, the goods and/or services are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of
confusion analysis.
Conclusion
Because the marks are similar and the goods and/or services are related, there is a likelihood of
confusion as to the source of applicant’s goods and/or services, and registration is refused pursuant to
Section 2(d) of the Trademark Act.
Response Options to Refusals
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal(s) by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration.

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97585816


MARK: JINDA 


Amended Goods and services
Class 025
Pajamas; Shirts; Skirts; Suits; Sweaters; Swimsuits; Trousers; Masquerade costumes; Swimming trunks; Tops as clothing 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 5825658 for JINDA HOME FASHION with a design for “Bed sheets; Comforters; Curtains; Cushion covers; Pillow cases; Pillow covers; Pillow shams; Bath linen; Bed linen and table linen; Fabric table runners; Fitted bed sheets; Household linen; Pillowcases; Table linen.” in International
Class 024. as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
"Jinda" is the pronunciation of the Chinese word "金达", which is the name of a gas station of the applicant's father. The applicant would like to use the same name as his father's business. JINDA is also a first name.

The consumer impression should be viewed in consideration of the mark as a whole, including the goods and disclaimed wording, which is still part of the mark.  Registration contains the wording HOME FASHION which indicates to consumers that the mark has to do with home fashion, like bedspreads and linens. Home fashion does not describe clothing like the Applicant’s goods. The consumer impression and connotation are therefore different between the marks. 

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Home fashion stores like Crate and Barrel sell linens and bedspreads, like the Registrant, but do not generally sell clothing like the applicant’s goods. The goods as well as the channels of trade are therefore different. Please see enclosed evidence from Crate and Barrel, where linens are sold but no clothing. Consumers would not expect a home fashion store to also sell clothing.
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 6077515. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Applicant has applied for the mark EVERMORE in standard characters for "Display racks; Shelves" in
Class 20.
Registrant owns the mark EVERMORE in standard characters for "Beverage glassware; Bowls;
Cooking pots and pans; Plates; Saucers; Serving trays" in Class 21.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Comparison of the Marks
In a likelihood of confusion determination, the marks in their entireties are compared for similarities in
appearance, sound, connotation, and commercial impression. In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315,
1323, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1748 (Fed. Cir. 2017); Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP,
746 F.3d 1317, 1321, 110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve
Clicquot Ponsardin Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir.
2005)); In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A.
1973); TMEP §1207.01(b)-(b)(v).
In the present case, applicant’s mark is EVERMORE and registrant’s mark is EVERMORE. These
marks are identical in appearance, sound, and meaning, “and have the potential to be used . . . in
exactly the same manner.” In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 116 USPQ2d 1406, 1411 (TTAB 2015), aff’d, 866
F.3d 1315, 123 USPQ2d 1744 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Additionally, because they are identical, these marks
are likely to engender the same connotation and overall commercial impression when considered in
connection with applicant’s and registrant’s respective goods and/or services. Id.
Therefore, the marks are confusingly similar.
Relatedness of the Goods
The goods are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related, or travel in the
same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369-71, 101
USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1165,
64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
In the present case, applicant's display racks and shelves are related to registrant's beverage glassware,
bowls, cooking pots and pans, plates, saucers and serving trays. The attached Internet evidence from
William Sonoma, Crate & Barrel and Sur La Table establishes that the same entity commonly provides
display racks, shelves, glassware, bowls, cooking pots and pans, plates, saucers and serving trays, and
markets the goods under the same mark. See the attached website screen captures. Thus, applicant’s
and registrant’s goods are considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re
Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91
USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Therefore, because the marks are confusingly similar and the goods are closely related, purchasers
encountering the goods of applicant and registrant are likely to mistakenly believe that they emanate
from a common source. Accordingly, registration is refused pursuant to Section 2(d) of the Trademark
Act.
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal(s) by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97538589


MARK: EVERMORE


Amended Goods and services
Class 020
Display racks for trophies and awards; Shelves for trophies and awards

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 6077515 for EVERMORE in standard characters for "Beverage glassware; Bowls; Cooking pots and pans; Plates; Saucers; Serving trays" in Class 21 as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
Registration is for EVERMORE for “Beverage glassware; Bowls; Cooking pots and pans; Plates; Saucers; Serving trays,” while  Applicant’s mark is for “Display racks for trophies and awards; Shelves for trophies and awards.” The connotation of a trademark is determined in relation to the mark and the goods, and in this case the goods are quite different, leaving the consumer with a different impression and connotation of the marks. 

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The application is for trophy cases (Amazon listing is enclosed). The title of the listing is “medal hanger display and trophy shelf”. The goods ID  has been amended to clarify this.

Trophies and awards are in very different channels of trade from  "Beverage glassware; Bowls; Cooking pots and pans; Plates; Saucers; Serving trays", which are all present in the kitchen. Trophies come from (typically) athletic endeavors and are to memorialize the event for the competitor. In the case of a child, the trophies may be kept in a bedroom and for an adult there may be a trophy case in the living room, but trophies and awards are not used for eating and are far removed from kitchen goods. The same is true for display shelves for trophies and awards.

Further, stores that sell kitchen goods do not also sell trophy cases and shelves. A search of “trophy” and “trophy shelf” on Crate and Barrel came up with no results. 
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 2002031. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP

Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re

record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Similarity of the Marks
Applicant has applied to register the stylized mark SUNTEK owned by Shanghai Suntek Technology
Co.
Registrant’s mark is SUNTECH with a design owned by Sunmatch Industrial Co.
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, SUNTEK, is confusingly similar to phonetic equivalent, SUNTECH, in
registrant's mark in appearance, sound, meaning, and overall commercial impression. This is because
marks sound the same since the "K" and "CH" at the end of the word "SUNTE" make the same hard
"K" sound.
The marks are essentially phonetic equivalents and thus sound similar. Similarity in sound alone may
be sufficient to support a finding that the compared marks are confusingly similar. In re 1st USA Realty
Prof’ls, Inc., 84 USPQ2d 1581, 1586 (TTAB 2007) (citing Krim-Ko Corp. v. Coca-Cola Bottling Co.,
390 F.2d 728, 732, 156 USPQ 523, 526 (C.C.P.A. 1968)); TMEP §1207.01(b)(iv).
The roots of these marks are the same, both starting with "SUN" and ending with a version of the word
"TECH," sometimes spelled "TEK."
Marks may be confusingly similar in appearance where similar terms or phrases or similar parts of
terms or phrases appear in the compared marks and create a similar overall commercial impression. See
Crocker Nat’l Bank v. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, 228 USPQ 689, 690-91 (TTAB 1986),
aff’d sub nom. Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce v. Wells Fargo Bank, Nat’l Ass’n, 811 F.2d 1490,
1495, 1 USPQ2d 1813, 1817 (Fed. Cir. 1987) (holding COMMCASH and COMMUNICASH
confusingly similar); In re Corning Glass Works, 229 USPQ 65, 66 (TTAB 1985) (holding CONFIRM
and CONFIRMCELLS confusingly similar); In re Pellerin Milnor Corp., 221 USPQ 558, 560 (TTAB
1983) (holding MILTRON and MILLTRONICS confusingly similar); TMEP §1207.01(b)(ii)-(iii).
Because the marks have the same meaning, look and sound similar, and create the same commercial
impression, the marks are considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods and/or Services
Applicant has applied to register for “Lawnmowers; Snowblowers; Automatic swimming pool cleaners
and parts therefor; Chain saws; Chains for chain saws; Electric chain saws; Electric hedge trimmers;
Electric lawn mowers; Electric lawn trimmers; Electric lawnmowers; High pressure washers; Lawn and
garden string trimmer spools; Lawn mower blades; Lawn mowers; Power-operated blowers; Power-
operated cultivators; Power-operated grass/weed trimmers; Power-operated lawn and garden string
trimmers; Power blowers for lawn debris; Replacement parts for chain saws, namely, bars and chains;
Riding lawn mowers; Robotic lawnmowers; Scissors, electric; Screwdrivers, electric; Vacuum
cleaners” in International Class 007.
Cited registration is for “Machine tools; namely, air screwdriver, air drill, reversible drill, random
orbital sander dust free random orbital sander, wet sander, spray gun, cut-off tools, punch, angle
grinder, metal shear, air hammer, blow gun” in International Class 007.
The goods and/or services are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related,
or travel in the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356,
1369-71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods, “Lawnmowers; Snowblowers; Automatic swimming pool cleaners and parts
therefor; Chain saws; Chains for chain saws; Electric chain saws; Electric hedge trimmers; Electric
lawn mowers; Electric lawn trimmers; Electric lawnmowers; High pressure washers; Lawn and garden
string trimmer spools; Lawn mower blades; Lawn mowers; Power-operated blowers; Power-operated
cultivators; Power-operated grass/weed trimmers; Power-operated lawn and garden string trimmers;
Power blowers for lawn debris; Replacement parts for chain saws, namely, bars and chains; Riding
lawn mowers; Robotic lawnmowers; Scissors, electric; Screwdrivers, electric; Vacuum cleaners” are
closely related to registrant’s goods, “Machine tools; namely, air screwdriver, air drill, reversible drill,
random orbital sander dust free random orbital sander, wet sander, spray gun, cut-off tools, punch,
angle grinder, metal shear, air hammer, blow gun.” This is because both parties' goods include types of
handy and construction tools, often produced and sold by the same company. It is common for the same
company to produce and market the referenced goods under the same mark. Thus, the goods have the
same class of purchasers and are likely to be encountered under circumstances that would cause one to
mistakenly believe the goods emanate from the same source.
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of the websites for Craftsman, Black and Decker, Makita
Tools, Milwaukee Tools, and DeWalt, establishes that the same entity commonly manufactures,
produces, or provides the relevant goods and/or services and markets the goods and/or services under
the same mark. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or services are considered related for
likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04
(TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Thus, encountering SUNTEK and SUNTECH, used on the identified goods, consumers are likely to be
confused and mistakenly believe that the respective goods emanate from a common source.
Accordingly, the goods are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of confusion analysis.
Conclusion
Because the marks are similar and the goods and/or services are related, there is a likelihood of
confusion as to the source of applicant’s goods and/or services, and registration is refused pursuant to
Section 2(d) of the Trademark Act.
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusa by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration.

U.S. APPLICATION SERIAL NO. 97491851


MARK: SUNTEK

Amended Goods and services
Class 007
Lawnmowers; Snowblowers; Automatic swimming pool cleaners and parts therefor; Chain saws; Chains for chain saws; Electric chain saws; Electric hedge trimmers; Electric lawn mowers; Electric lawn trimmers; Electric lawnmowers; High pressure washers; Lawn and garden string trimmer spools; Lawn mower blades; Lawn mowers; Power-operated blowers; Power-operated cultivators; Power-operated grass/weed trimmers; Power-operated lawn and garden string trimmers; Power blowers for lawn debris; Replacement parts for chain saws, namely, bars and chains; Riding lawn mowers; Robotic lawnmowers; Scissors, electric; Screwdrivers, electric; Vacuum cleaners 

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 2002031 (SUNTECH for “machine tools; namely, air screwdriver, air drill, reversible drill, random orbital sander dust free random orbital sander, wet sander, spray gun, cut-off tools, punch, angle grinder, metal shear, air hammer, blow gun” in class 007) as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.


The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. The words "when applied" do not refer to a mental exercise, but to all of the known circumstances surrounding use of the mark (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)).

It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.
The marks are somewhat different - SUNTEK vs SUNTECH in a circular design. The SUNTECH would be more indicative of technology (“tech”) relating to the sun. SUNTEK doesn’t share that connotation since TEK has no clear meaning.
Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. Tarmann, 75 U.S.P.Q.2d 1811, 1820–21 (T.T.A.B.2005) (finding that BLUE MAN GROUP “has the connotation of the appearance of the performers” and that applicant's BLUEMAN mark “has no such connotation for cigarettes or tobacco. Thus, the marks differ in their connotations and commercial impressions”) (Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012). In the Coach case, even though the marks were identical the commercial impression was found to be very different, and no likelihood of confusion was found by the Court.
The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
The goods are quite different. Those of the Registrant are all machine tools: “machine tools; namely, air screwdriver, air drill, reversible drill, random orbital sander dust free random orbital sander, wet sander, spray gun, cut-off tools, punch, angle grinder, metal shear, air hammer, blow gun.“ These are sold through hardware stores or specialty tool and industrial equipment stores. 

Applicant’s products on the other hand are mainly for the garden: “Lawnmowers; Snowblowers; Automatic swimming pool cleaners and parts therefor; Chain saws; Chains for chain saws; Electric chain saws; Electric hedge trimmers; Electric lawn mowers; Electric lawn trimmers; Electric lawnmowers; High pressure washers; Lawn and garden string trimmer spools; Lawn mower blades; Lawn mowers; Power-operated blowers; Power-operated cultivators; Power-operated grass/weed trimmers; Power-operated lawn and garden string trimmers; Power blowers for lawn debris; Replacement parts for chain saws, namely, bars and chains; Riding lawn mowers; Robotic lawnmowers; Scissors, electric; Screwdrivers, electric; Vacuum cleaners.” There are no machine tools or other tools in the listing that would travel through similar channels of trade, and consumers would understand the difference in the products and their uses.

While home stores like Home Depot might sell both machine tools and garden machines they would sell them in very different sections. The hardware and tool section is right in the middle of a Home Depot store (sold all year long) while the Garden Center is on one of the sides, and is typically seasonal. That is where the garden machines would also be sold. 

Machine tools are dangerous as well, and have very specific uses that only a professional or serious hobbyist would understand. These people who purchase machine tools are sophisticated purchasers who know precisely what tool they need to fit the machine and carry out the task, as well as how to avoid injury. 
The fame of the prior mark (sales, advertising, length of use).
The Registration does not appear to be famous.
The nature and extent of any actual confusion.
There is no evidence of actual confusion. 
It is submitted that the DuPont factors weigh in favor of the Applicant’s mark, such that there is no likelihood of confusion with the cited Registration.

prompt:
Registration of the applied-for mark is refused because of a likelihood of confusion with the mark in
U.S. Registration No. 2167204. Trademark Act Section 2(d), 15 U.S.C. §1052(d); see TMEP
§§1207.01 et seq. See the attached registration.
Trademark Act Section 2(d) bars registration of an applied-for mark that is so similar to a registered
mark that it is likely consumers would be confused, mistaken, or deceived as to the commercial source
of the goods and/or services of the parties. See 15 U.S.C. §1052(d). Likelihood of confusion is
determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the factors set forth in In re E. I. du Pont de Nemours
& Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361, 177 USPQ 563, 567 (C.C.P.A. 1973) (called the “du Pont factors”). In re
i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d 1315, 1322, 123 USPQ2d 1744, 1747 (Fed. Cir. 2017). Any evidence of
record related to those factors need be considered; however, “not all of the DuPont factors are relevant
or of similar weight in every case.” In re Guild Mortg. Co., 912 F.3d 1376, 1379, 129 USPQ2d 1160,
1162 (Fed. Cir. 2019) (quoting In re Dixie Rests., Inc., 105 F.3d 1405, 1406, 41 USPQ2d 1531, 1533
(Fed. Cir. 1997)).
Although not all du Pont factors may be relevant, there are generally two key considerations in any
likelihood of confusion analysis: (1) the similarities between the compared marks and (2) the
relatedness of the compared goods and/or services. See In re i.am.symbolic, llc, 866 F.3d at 1322, 123
USPQ2d at 1747 (quoting Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308 F.3d 1156, 1164-65, 64
USPQ2d 1375, 1380 (Fed. Cir. 2002)); Federated Foods, Inc. v. Fort Howard Paper Co., 544 F.2d
1098, 1103, 192 USPQ 24, 29 (C.C.P.A. 1976) (“The fundamental inquiry mandated by [Section] 2(d)
goes to the cumulative effect of differences in the essential characteristics of the goods [or services] and
differences in the marks.”); TMEP §1207.01.
Applicant has applied to register the mark LE PORTTEUS in standard characters for “Decanters; Wine
decanters” in International Class 021.
Registrant’s mark is PORTTEUS in standard characters for “wine” in International Class 033.
Similarity of the Marks
Marks are compared in their entireties for similarities in appearance, sound, connotation, and
commercial impression. Stone Lion Capital Partners, LP v. Lion Capital LLP, 746 F.3d 1317, 1321,
110 USPQ2d 1157, 1160 (Fed. Cir. 2014) (quoting Palm Bay Imps., Inc. v. Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin
Maison Fondee En 1772, 396 F.3d 1369, 1371, 73 USPQ2d 1689, 1691 (Fed. Cir. 2005)); TMEP
§1207.01(b)-(b)(v). “Similarity in any one of these elements may be sufficient to find the marks
confusingly similar.” In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018) (citing In re
Davia, 110 USPQ2d 1810, 1812 (TTAB 2014)), aff’d per curiam, 777 F. App’x 516, 2019 BL 343921
(Fed. Cir. 2019); TMEP §1207.01(b).
Here, applicant’s mark, LE PORTTEUS, is confusingly similar to the registered mark, PORTTEUS.
Here, Applicant's mark appears to be identical except for the addition of the term LE to the front of the
mark. The addition of this term does little to differentiate these two marks. Each appears to be
identifying a common PORTTEUS source.
When comparing marks, “[t]he proper test is not a side-by-side comparison of the marks, but instead
whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression such that
[consumers] who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties.”
Cai v. Diamond Hong, Inc., 901 F.3d 1367, 1373, 127 USPQ2d 1797, 1801 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (quoting
Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356, 1368, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1721 (Fed. Cir.
2012)); TMEP §1207.01(b). The proper focus is on the recollection of the average purchaser, who
retains a general rather than specific impression of trademarks. In re Ox Paperboard, LLC, 2020
USPQ2d 10878, at *4 (TTAB 2020) (citing In re Bay State Brewing Co., 117 USPQ2d 1958, 1960
(TTAB 2016)); In re Inn at St. John’s, LLC, 126 USPQ2d 1742, 1746 (TTAB 2018); TMEP
§1207.01(b); see In re St. Helena Hosp., 774 F.3d 747, 750-51, 113 USPQ2d 1082, 1085 (Fed. Cir.
2014).
Marks must be compared in their entireties and should not be dissected; however, a trademark
examining attorney may weigh the individual components of a mark to determine its overall
commercial impression. In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128 USPQ2d 1047, 1050
(Fed. Cir. 2018) (“[Regarding the issue of confusion,] there is nothing improper in stating that . . . more
or less weight has been given to a particular feature of a mark, provided the ultimate conclusion rests
on consideration of the marks in their entireties.” (quoting In re Nat’l Data Corp., 753 F.2d 1056, 1058,
224 USPQ 749, 751 (Fed. Cir. 1985)).
Although marks are compared in their entireties, one feature of a mark may be more significant or
dominant in creating a commercial impression. See In re Detroit Athletic Co., 903 F.3d 1297, 1305, 128
USPQ2d 1047, 1050 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (citing In re Dixie Rests., 105 F.3d 1405, 1407, 41 USPQ2d
1531, 1533-34 (Fed. Cir. 1997)); TMEP §1207.01(b)(viii), (c)(ii). Greater weight is often given to this
dominant feature when determining whether marks are confusingly similar. See In re Detroit Athletic
Co., 903 F.3d at 1305, 128 USPQ2d at 1050 (citing In re Dixie Rests., 105 F.3d at 1407, 41 USPQ2d at
1533-34). The dominant portion of each mark is the term PORTTEUS, which appears with identical
spelling in each mark. For Registrant's mark, this term is the primary component of the standard
character mark. Similarly, the term PORTTEUS is the longest and most distinctive term in the mark.
The additional matter in the appliaction is the term LE, which consumers may see as analagous to
adding the word "the" to the front of the term PORTTEUS.
Adding a term to a registered mark generally does not obviate the similarity between the compared
marks, as in the present case, nor does it overcome a likelihood of confusion under Section 2(d). See
Coca-Cola Bottling Co. v. Jos. E. Seagram & Sons, Inc., 526 F.2d 556, 557, 188 USPQ 105, 106
(C.C.P.A. 1975) (holding BENGAL and BENGAL LANCER and design confusingly similar); In re
Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266, 1269 (TTAB 2009) (holding TITAN and VANTAGE
TITAN confusingly similar); In re El Torito Rests., Inc., 9 USPQ2d 2002, 2004 (TTAB 1988) (holding
MACHO and MACHO COMBOS confusingly similar); TMEP §1207.01(b)(iii). In the present case,
the marks are identical in part. Each mark shares the identical and dominant term PORTTEUS.
When comparing similar marks, the Trademark Trial and Appeal Board has found that inclusion of the
term “the” at the beginning of one of the marks will generally not affect or otherwise diminish the
overall similarity between the marks. See In re Thor Tech Inc., 90 USPQ2d 1634, 1635 (TTAB 2009)
(finding WAVE and THE WAVE “virtually identical” marks; “[t]he addition of the word ‘The’ at the
beginning of the registered mark does not have any trademark significance.”); In re Narwood Prods.
Inc., 223 USPQ 1034, 1034 (TTAB 1984) (finding THE MUSIC MAKERS and MUSIC-MAKERS
“virtually identical” marks; the inclusion of the definite article “the” is “insignificant in determining
likelihood of confusion”). Here, Applicant's mark features the inclusion of the term LE at the beginning
of their mark. The attached article from Rocket Languages explains that LE means "the" in French.
Functionally, the addition of this term is analagous to adding the word "the" to the front of a registered
mark. This addition does little to change the overall commercial impression of these marks.
Overall, these marks appear to identify a common PORTTEUS source.
Because the marks look and sound similar and create the same commercial impression, the marks are
considered similar for likelihood of confusion purposes.
Relatedness of the Goods and/or Services
The goods and/or services are compared to determine whether they are similar, commercially related,
or travel in the same trade channels. See Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668 F.3d 1356,
1369-71, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722-23 (Fed. Cir. 2012); Herbko Int’l, Inc. v. Kappa Books, Inc., 308
F.3d 1156, 1165, 64 USPQ2d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2002); TMEP §§1207.01, 1207.01(a)(vi).
The compared goods and/or services need not be identical or even competitive to find a likelihood of
confusion. See On-line Careline Inc. v. Am. Online Inc., 229 F.3d 1080, 1086, 56 USPQ2d 1471, 1475
(Fed. Cir. 2000); Recot, Inc. v. Becton, 214 F.3d 1322, 1329, 54 USPQ2d 1894, 1898 (Fed. Cir. 2000);
TMEP §1207.01(a)(i). They need only be “related in some manner and/or if the circumstances
surrounding their marketing are such that they could give rise to the mistaken belief that [the goods
and/or services] emanate from the same source.” Coach Servs., Inc. v. Triumph Learning LLC, 668
F.3d 1356, 1369, 101 USPQ2d 1713, 1722 (Fed. Cir. 2012) (quoting 7-Eleven Inc. v. Wechsler, 83
USPQ2d 1715, 1724 (TTAB 2007)); TMEP §1207.01(a)(i); see Made in Nature, LLC v. Pharmavite
LLC, 2022 USPQ2d 557, at *44 (TTAB 2022) (quoting In re Jump Designs LLC, 80 USPQ2d 1370,
1374 (TTAB 2006)).
Here, applicant’s goods, “Decanters; Wine decanters,” are closely related to registrant’s goods, “wine.”
The attached Internet evidence, consisting of product pages from Benessere Vineyards, Biltmore, Broc,
Francis Ford Coppola, Justin, and Patz & Hall establishes that the same entity commonly manufactures,
produces, or provides the relevant goods and/or services and markets the goods and/or services under
the same mark. Wine decanters are made for use with wines. The attached evidence shows that entities
that sell wines also sell decanters for those wines. Thus, applicant’s and registrant’s goods and/or
services are considered related for likelihood of confusion purposes. See, e.g., In re Davey Prods. Pty
Ltd., 92 USPQ2d 1198, 1202-04 (TTAB 2009); In re Toshiba Med. Sys. Corp., 91 USPQ2d 1266,
1268-69, 1271-72 (TTAB 2009).
Accordingly, the goods and/or services are considered related for purposes of the likelihood of
confusion analysis.
Conclusion
Because the marks are similar and the goods are related, there is a likelihood of confusion as to the
source of applicant’s goods and/or services, and registration is refused pursuant to Section 2(d) of the
Trademark Act.
Response Options to Refusals
Although applicant’s mark has been refused registration, applicant may respond to the refusal by
submitting evidence and arguments in support of registration

Amended Goods and services

Section 2(d) Likelihood of Confusion Refusal 

The Examiner has cited U.S. Registration No. 2167204 (PORTTEUS for “wine” in class 033) as having a likelihood of confusion with the application under 2d.

The purpose of a likelihood of confusion analysis is for the benefit of the Registrants, to determine “whether the marks are sufficiently similar in terms of their commercial impression” such that persons who encounter the marks would be likely to assume a connection between the parties. Leading Jewelers Guild, 82 U.S.P.Q.2d at 1905.

But the question of confusion is related not to the nature of the mark but to its effect "when applied to the goods of the applicant." The only relevant application is made in the marketplace. It is proper to consider the E.I. DuPont Factors (In re E.I. DuPont DeNemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (CCPA 1973)):
The similarity or dissimilarity of the marks in their entireties as to appearance, sound, connotation and commercial impression.

Even where the marks at issue are identical, or nearly identical, the Board has found that differences in connotation can outweigh visual and phonetic similarity. See Blue Man Prods. Inc. v. The similarity or dissimilarity of and nature of the goods or services as described in an application or registration or in connection with which a prior mark is in use.
Applicant’s goods are for decanters - even though they are for wine it is unusual for a wine company, that makes a consumable product, to also make household kitchen goods like decanters.
